DOC.HEAD: Squirrel is Nuts About Grocery Living
DOC.TEXT: Employees of a grocery store are losing patience with the continuing escapades of a squirrel that has taken up residence amid the coffee cakes, doughnuts and hot dog rolls. The critter has run up a $25 tab at the Farm Fare IGA over the last two weeks. Employees took to shooing the squirrel outside, but it keeps coming back. ``It was a joke the first couple of times, but now he is beginning to be a problem,'' said store manager Dick Emery. The squirrel once jumped over a woman's shoulder as she reached for a box of rice, leaving her shrieking as it high-tailed it up the aisle. ``I came in one morning and there he was, just sitting down on top of the wine coolers in the front of the store,'' Emery said. ``It was almost as if he was waiting for the chase to begin.'' Fritz Sabbow, executive director of the local Humane Society, said the only way to catch the squirrel will be with a net ``and it won't be easy. They are pretty quick.''

DOC.HEAD: 45,000 Bottles of Solution Recalled
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling to Opticrom sted Opricrom
DOC.TEXT: More than 45,000 bottles of a prescription eye solution are being recalled because that may be contaminated with bacteria that could cause a sight-threatening infection in a scratched eye, officials said Friday. The product made by Fisons Corp. of Rochester, N.Y., is Opticrom, generically known as cromolyn sodium, in a 4 percent ophthalmic solution. It is sold in 10 milliliter bottles, the Food and Drug Administration said. The two lots being recalled are KF7A and KF35V. The lot identification appears on the bottom of the bottle and also on the flap of the cardboard container the bottle comes in. The FDA advises consumers to return bottles in these lots to their pharmacies. The solution is prescribed to treat several rare eye conditions. Testing by Fisons PLC Pharmaceutical Division in the United Kingdom found Bacillus cereus in lot KF7A, and an unidentified bacillus in the other lot, the FDA said. Both lots were distributed nationwide and in Puerto Rico. The FDA said that about 114 bottles of KF7A and 45,223 bottles of KF35V were distributed.

DOC.HEAD: Qualifying Scores for Math Teachers are Lowered as Need Increases
With PM-Math Teachers-Scores, PM-Math Teachers-Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: If math teachers are asked 98 questions on a certification test, how many do they have to get right to pass? A.) 90; B.) 70; C.) 60, or D.) 49. In a new certification test in Florida, the correct answer is C. And although a score of 60 would earn most students a D on a math exam, the Florida standard is high compared to some other states. Fifteen states use a different exam, developed by a national testing company, and have established cutoff scores that range from approximately 35 percent of 150 questions to a high of approximately 55 percent. ``It won't do any good to have passing scores ... that nobody can reach,'' said Tom Fisher, head of testing for the Florida Department of Education. The supply and demand of teachers is a problem that always confronts states as they debate certification requirements, said Catherine Havrilesky, executive director of teacher programs at Educational Testing Service (ETS) in Princeton, N.J. And math teachers are in short supply everywhere, according to Iris Carl, president of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics and director of mathematics for the Houston Independent School District. Marita Eng, a high school math teacher in Jacksonville who sat on an advisory panel that recommended a higher cutoff score in Florida, said international comparisons of student performance show that the United States is in the middle of a ``crisis in mathematics education.'' One of the problems, Eng said, is poorly prepared teachers. Carl conceded the scores required of math teachers across the nation seem low and concern her. However, defenders of the testing system point out that the exams include hard questions and aren't designed to result in extremely high scores. The ETS developed the 150-question test used by 15 states. It also offers tests in about 40 other subjects. Some of the other cutoff scores include from 50 percent to 55 percent for early childhood education, from 40 percent to 45 percent in earth-space science, from 40 percent to 55 percent for chemistry, and from 40 percent to 60 percent in physics. In math, the low qualifying score was set by Kentucky at 35 percent and the high by California at 55 percent. Rod Roth, who worked on adoption of the ETS test in Arkansas, said he didn't think the overall national standards were low. The test is designed to spread out the results by including some very difficult questions, according to Roth, now dean of the College of Education at the University of Alabama at Tuscaloosa. The ETS' Havrikesky said the important issue about the math test was whether it was fair. Besides the 15 states that use the ETS test, four are considering adopting it. Five other states have customized tests developed with the help of National Evaluation Systems in Amherst, Mass. NES does not have figures for those states. Probably about a third of the states don't require specific math certification tests for teachers, according to Roth. Emily Feistritzer, director of the National Center for Education Information, a private research organization in Washington, called it shocking that each state sets its own teacher certification standards. ``The data is so scattered _ there really is no national data as far as teachers are concerned,'' she said. But Carl noted that the same 1987 study that put the best U.S. students near the bottom in international math ability found that most high school math teachers in the United States were better trained than their Japanese counterparts. Fisher, of the Florida Education Department, recommended to Gov. Bob Martinez and the cabinet last month that the state require a cutoff score of 49. Fisher based his arguments on the performance record established by the first several hundred people to take Florida's test. If prospective math teachers were required to correctly answer half the test, two-thirds would probably pass, he said. Martinez and the cabinet members said 49 was too low. But they also rejected an advisory panel's suggestions that the state establish a score of 70. If the state had adopted that standard, only 14 percent of the first 332 people to take the math test would have passed. With a passing score of 60, the success rate is expected to be 37 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Flood of Outsiders Has Changed Hemingway's Fiesta
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It is 7:30 a.m., time for the new daily ritual that precedes the one Ernest Hemingway made famous. An hour before the running of the bulls, a line of 30 policemen sweeps down the blocked-off cobblestone streets that lead from Pamplona's corrals to the bullring, clearing out drunken revelers. Street cleaning machines follow, armed with high-powered hoses that blast away another night's accumulation of plastic cups, champagne bottles and other trash _ 700 tons each day, according to one local newspaper. This year's raucous, weeklong San Fermin festival was to end today. The annual fiesta, immortalized in Hemingway's 1926 novel, ``The Sun Also Rises,'' has been held continuously since 1591, but the flood of foreigners who now attend has changed the nature of San Fermin. ``The main problem is that it's overcrowded,'' said Jose Miguel Olaiz, who helps coordinate the Navarre regional government's special 12-ambulance emergency service during the festival. ``When I was a kid, we were mostly locals with a few outsiders. Now it's the opposite,'' the 37-year-old Pamplona native said. Many locals leave the city during the fiesta to avoid the noise and crush. Handling the media takes up so much time now that the regional emergency service last year began sending out daily faxes with information on gorings and other injuries. The computerized information is broken down according to age, sex, time of day and type of injury. Records kept since the festival began indicate 52 people have met their deaths on the horns of running bulls, 13 since 1924 when Hemingway reportedly first saw the event. The morning running of the bulls, which usually lasts no more than five minutes, is covered live on national television and radio. More than 100 people, mainly young men, test their mettle by running ahead of and alongside the bulls and six steers along the half-mile route to the bullring, where the bulls are killed in the day's bullfight. City fathers now issue special passes to limit the number of photographers and cameramen allowed on the specially built barricades that separate the bulls and runners from the public. They have also tried to reduce the number of people who run with the bulls during the annual festival, which honors the patron saint of Pamplona, a city of 200,000. Up to 100 people _ some of them first-timers pumped up by alcohol _ now join the core group of 20-30 natives or ``mozos,'' who carry rolled up newspapers to fend off the bulls. The novices sometimes get in the way of the natives and occasionally mistreat the bulls and steers. This week, one youth dressed in the traditional white shirt and pants and red bandanna punched another runner who hit a bull. Women traditionally do not run with the bulls and few are ever seen among the runners. The number of tourists has also increased the incidence of injuries related to drunkenness, Olaiz said. ``It's not that the local people drink less, but at least they go home at the end of the night,'' he said. ``Some of the foreigners seem to come expressly to drink _ they don't understand the spirit of the fiesta.'' Since the hotels are filled to overflowing, many foreigners sleep less than the youth of Pamplona, who generally don't go to bed until the 8 a.m. running of the bulls is over. Families that begin their day with the daily bull run now are oblivious to sleeping revelers stretched out on city benches, on top of cars, in doorways and on park grass. But the worst time of the day, according to the Navarre emergency services faxes, comes at around 3 p.m. ``That's when the energy level of the fiesta goes down and people who have been drinking sit down and realize just how bad off they are,'' Olaiz said.

DOC.HEAD: For One Family, Embassy Occupation a Ticket to Freedom
With PM-Albania, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: It was the moment Arjan Xhaferi had been waiting for. Hundreds of Albanians were surging into foreign embassies in the capital, he learned one night two weeks ago. In no time, the 32-year-old factory worker was on the phone to his friends in Shkodar, a city in northern Albania. ``I said, `Hurry, we can win our liberty,''' he recalled. A few nights later, Xhaferi, his pregnant wife, his daughter and their friends clambered over the wall of the West German Embassy in Tirana. On Friday, they were among more than 4,000 people who were ferried out of Albania to Italy in a sealift set up through U.N. mediation. ``I have sacrificed everything _ even my life,'' said Xhaferi, speaking in Italian. ``We have searched for liberty for so much time.'' He gazed at his wife, who was smiling despite the heat and fatigue, a hand resting on her swollen belly. ``We hope the baby is free,'' he said, grinning shyly. The Xhaferis had some particular reasons for being unhappy in Albania. A friend had tried unsuccessfully to flee the country, and his family was under pressure from the government, Xhaferi said. But they had more general reasons too: the poor quality of life and the ban on the practice of religion, which hurt the Roman Catholic family. Albania was 70 percent Moslem before the government closed all mosques and churches in 1967. ``We want freedom, we want a new economy, a new government and a new society _ of democracy,'' Xhaferi declared. While the West German Embassy provided the door to a new life, the Xhaferis did not have an easy time there. Every day, the Albanian government shut off the water for several hours in the building, packed with 3,200 refugees. Toilets stopped working and overflowed. Men slept in a few rooms, crowded on the floor; women and children in other rooms. Nonetheless, he says, West German diplomats were ``wonderful,'' giving them meat and bread, as well as milk for 5-year-old Arrisa. The Xhaferis finally got to leave the embassy late Thursday, after ferries sent by Western European governments for the refugees docked in the port of Durres. But the ordeal was not over yet. The heat in the government-owned busses was oppressively high, and it was impossible to open the windows, Xhaferi said. Their ferry left at 3 a.m. Friday and pulled into port seven hours later. Still ahead for the family was a 30-hour train trip to West Germany. But there were no complaints. ``We are leaving communism forever,'' Xhaferi grinned.

DOC.HEAD: Currency Expert Calls for More Attractive Greenbacks
DOC.TEXT: While the government is redesigning currency to thwart counterfeiters, it ought to make the bills more attractive, says a man who used to run the Treasury's money-producing agency. ``The principles and history of a country are recounted in the art of bank notes,'' Robert J. Leuver told the Senate Banking Committee on Friday. ``We seem to have lost the art, majesty and history provided in our national bank notes of 1896, silver certificates of 1896 and the beautiful $2 bill of 1976.'' ``The `Tin Lizzy' (vintage car) on the back of the $10 bill harkens to a different time and does not afford the counterfeit detection we need,'' said Leuver, a former chief of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing who now directs the American Numismatic Association. Leuver said most of the anti-counterfeiting deterrents built into currency are less effective than they could be because of the 50-year-old design of the bills. As an example, he mentioned the mylar ``security thread'' that soon will become a part of every greenback. The thread will include printing that can be read only in indirect light. ``This deterrent will particularly thwart counterfeiters who ply their trade outside of the United States,'' he said. ``However, the current design of the note ... obscures the thread or causes it to be overlooked.'' Leuver, along with officials from the Secret Service and the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, endorsed a bill to toughen laws against counterfeiting. Carl V. D'Alessandro, assistant director of the bureau, told the committee that currency and other securities can be counterfeited with remarkable accuracy using widely available computers, printers and copiers. ``The potential counterfeiter no longer requires any particular expertise in printing, but only the inclination and the electronic devices,'' he said. ``Just as the counterfeiting of currency by multicolored copiers has increased greatly over the past few years, so will the use of computer laser scanners as a means to scan, store and subsequently counterfeit currency,'' said William J. Ebert, who heads the Secret Service's counterfeit division. Ebert said $13.8 million of counterfeit currency was passed in this country last year and $75.2 million was seized before it was put into circulation. Some $103 million in bogus U.S. bills was confiscated abroad. The measure D'Allesandro and Ebert endorsed would make it a crime to possess any laser-type device the Treasury Department concludes would help a counterfeiter, and would ensure that duplication of currency by any electronic method is illegal. It would bar private possession of any counterfeit-deterrent device, including watermarks and seals, just as the distinctive paper on which greenbacks are printed now is protected. But Kenneth A. Wasch, executive director of the Software Publishers Association, whose members develop computer programs, said the bill is so broad that ``many heretofore legal activities may now be made illegal.'' He said the prohibition on private possession of certain optical devices could ``mean document scanners, desktop computers, a number of software programs, laser printers and other high-tech wonders could be outlawed even though they are in use everywhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Eager to Sign Anti-Bias Bill for Handicapped
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is eager to sign civil rights legislation aimed at drawing millions of disabled Americans into the work force and marketplace. ``This legislation will serve as a declaration of independence for millions of persons with disabilities in this country,'' Bush said Friday after a 91-6 Senate vote sent the Americans With Disabilities Act to the White House. ``It will change the way we live forever,'' said the chief Senate sponsor, Democrat Tom Harkin of Iowa. In a dramatic conclusion of nine months of debate on the bill, Harkin addressed the Senate in sign language as a tribute to his brother Frank, who is deaf. ``I wanted to say to my brother Frank that today was my proudest day in 16 years in Congress,'' Harkin explained. The bill aims at doing for people with mental and physical impairments what the 1964 Civil Rights Act strived to do for blacks and other minorities. It bans discrimination against the disabled in employment, public accommodations, transportation and telecommunications. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would sign the bill into law as soon as a ceremony could be arranged, probably as early as next week. Fitzwater called the measure one of the `most important accomplishments of this administration.'' Civil rights lobbyists complain that the White House did little to help the bill after the Senate initially passed it last September by a 76-8 vote. Friday's vote was on a compromise version. ``There's no question that President Bush and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh played a constructive role in fashioning a bipartisan consensus in the Senate in 1989,'' said Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, an umbrella group for civil rights and labor organizations. ``We have applauded that effort.'' But Neas added: ``There's no question that since September 1989 the administration has done very little.'' In the meantime, the bill went through a series of House hearings, leading to House approval of its own version, 403-20, in May. The House passed the compromise, 377-28, Thursday night. Between the original votes in the House and Senate, lawmakers were lobbied strongly by the Chamber of Commerce and the National Federation of Independent Business, which complained the bill is excessively burdensome. Although a few minor concessions emerged, the Senate bill remained basically intact. The Senate bill had been refined after extensive negotiations with the White House. The bill was conceived in 1988 by the National Council on Disability, a 15-member commission appointed by President Reagan. The original legislation, introduced by Sen. Lowell Weicker, R-Conn., and cosponsored by Harkin, was scuttled because of various problems. Harkin sponsored the new bill last year. The final hurdle was an amendment from the House that would have let employers reassign AIDS-infected workers from food-handling duties. Under an agreement reached early Thursday by House and Senate negotiators, AIDS-infected workers could be reassigned only if the Department of Health and Human Services found that the disease could be passed along through contact with food. HHS Secretary Louis W. Sullivan and other officials say no evidence exists that AIDS is spread through food or casual contact. In an effort to ease its impact on business, lawmakers included language phasing in the bill's requirements. The bill also exempts from the hiring provisions businesses with fewer than 15 employees. Voting against the bill Friday were Sens. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo.; Jake Garn, R-Utah; Jesse Helms, R-N.C.; Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H.; Steve Symms, R-Idaho; and Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., Not voting were Sens. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va.; James A. McClure, R-Idaho; and Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Government Ignored Secret Pleas for Cancer Studies at Arms Plant
DOC.TEXT: The agency that ran nuclear weapons production in the 1940s rejected secret advice to study cancer risks for its workers, even though it knew some were exposed to large doses of radiation, documents show. Records of the Atomic Energy Commission also show that airborne emissions of radiation continued at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington state from the plant's start-up in 1944 until at least the mid-1950s. The AEC was a predecessor to the Energy Department, which owns all the government's nuclear arms factories. The government first acknowledged the Hanford problems publicly in 1986, although much information about radiation releases there is still classified as secret. On Thursday, a panel of health experts disclosed that one in 20 residents living near Hanford, on the Columbia River near Richland, Wash., between late 1944 and December 1947 absorbed a level of radiation equal to 1,200 times what the Energy Department now considers a safe limit. The panel of independent health specialists said the releases of radioactive iodine _ a byproduct of extracting plutonium from uranium _ were serious enough to justify a study of potential illnesses or deaths related to the emissions. The release of the report marked the first time the government has publicly acknowledged that radiation releases from its nuclear arms factories could have harmed human health. Yet the government was made aware shortly after the Hanford plant began operating in September 1944 that airborne contaminants posed serious health risks. In a March 1948 report, the radiation health and safety chief at Hanford wrote that emissions of radioactive particles from the plant's plutonium-processing buildings ``can produce radiation damage.'' He also said that ``the theoretical possibility of injury developing 10 to 15 years from now poses a serious problem.'' The Atomic Energy Commission rejected a recommendation by its biology and medicine advisory panel in early 1949 that studies be conducted on possible links between cancer and Hanford workers' exposure to radiation, AEC records show. The AEC records were cited in a December 1989 report by the Democratic majority staff of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee that recommended the Energy Department make public more of its long-secret data on radiation releases at Hanford. The latest government admission of potential health hazards to people near Hanford is part of an evolution of openness about nuclear weapons operations. In a 1945 government report that revealed the existence of the once-secret Hanford and other plants, an Army official involved in the project wrote: ``Factors of safety used in plant design and operation are so great that the hazards of the home and the family car are far greater for the personnel than any arising from the plants.'' Gene Plock, who worked as an engineer at Hanford's plutonium-processing buildings from 1946 to 1950, said in an interview Friday that he and others in his work crew were informed of the emissions problem in late 1946 _ months after it was discovered by General Electric Co., which ran Hanford under a government contract. Plock said he and some other workers then began wearing protective masks. He said he recommended that military guards outside the building also be informed, and that they be required to wear protective masks. He said GE rejected his suggestion. ``Their response was, `No, let's not alarm them,''' he said. The Hanford study released Thursday contains the most specific information known to the public about radiation releases at that facility. Yet it tells only part of the story of accidental and intentional emissions of radiation from Hanford. In addition to the radioactive iodine, significant amounts of plutonium particles, ruthenium, americium and other potentially cancer-causing products were released from processing stacks on the 560-square-mile plant in 1940s and '50s, according to AEC records.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Wants Adam and Eve Mural Covered Up
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: The creator of a huge outdoor mural depicting Adam and Eve on a beach refuses to bow to city pressure to add children and paint bathing suits on the nude pair. Mayor Sal Oliveri said the wall of a motel isn't the place for the mural, but artist Steven Kroeger vowed not to change a thing and pledged to go to court if the city takes action against his work. The mayor contends the 8-foot-tall by 24-foot-long mural at Sunray Lodge isn't in keeping with the city's family-oriented image. City officials want bathing suits _ and children _ added to the recently-drawn painting. ``It's just out of place. We don't want to start a style or trend of nude pictures on buildings,'' said Oliveri, who inspected the painting Thursday. Kroeger hired Miami attorney Ellis Rubin, who puts the wrangle in the same category as recent Broward County controversies over the propriety of a 2 Live Crew rap album and T-thong bathing suits. ``Broward County is now four-for-four,'' Rubin said. ``You can't buy certain records, you can't listen to certain music, you can't wear certain bathing suits and now you can't paint certain murals.'' Kroeger said he can't understand the fuss. ``Would they have put bathing suits on a Rubens?'' Motel owner Doris Ouellet called the controversy silly. ``This represents Adam and Eve in paradise,'' she said. ``In paradise, Adam and Eve didn't have children. They didn't wear bikinis, either.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Rocker David Lee Roth has caught the wary eye of city officials with a 20-foot-high portrait of a scantily-clad woman on the outside wall of a recording studio. The portrait, with Roth's name emblazoned across the woman's chest, is on the rear wall of Little Mountain Sound studio, where fans waiting for a peek of favorite rockers who record there have sprayed a montage of graffiti. Roth, former lead singer of Van Halen, commissioned the airbrushed artwork that went up last month as a ``poetic and symbolic tribute to the city of Vancouver,'' said his road manager, Eddie Anderson. ``What better (tribute) than a beautiful woman sitting amidst the city?'' Anderson said. City officials don't see it that way. They're getting complaints and have told the studio's owners they must apply for a wall mural permit. Even with a permit, the city may decide to order the portrait's removal, said Jack Perry, deputy chief licence inspector for the city. Among other rockers who use the studio are Bon Jovi, Aerosmith, Motley Crue and Whitesnake.

Singer John Phillips, who once had a $1,000-a-day cocaine habit, says he still struggles to avoid old temptations. ``The urge is indescribable sometimes,'' said the founder of the Mamas and the Papas, who performed with the band here Thursday night. Phillips, 54, said he managed to wean himself off drugs in a rehabilitation clinic after being arrested on drug charges in 1980. Recovery isn't easy, especially in the music business because drugs are easily obtained backstage, Phillips said. ``I'm much better around it (drugs) now. It takes a long time to get over cocaine.'' In his book, ``Papa John,'' Phillips describes a heroin addiction that nearly killed him, followed by a cocaine ``cure'' that left him addicted to that drug.

A vacationing Lech Walesa has broken his arm, state television reported. The accident occurred during the Solidarity leader's annual summer getaway in the Kaszubian Lakes region in northern Poland, where he has a cabin. There were contradictory versions of how it happened. State television reported Friday that Walesa fell from a ladder Thursday, breaking his right arm. It gave no further details. A source close to Walesa's office in Gdansk said he was told Walesa was injured in a traffic mishap Tuesday while driving his van loaded with lumber for cabin repairs. Walesa himself could not be reached for comment. His cabin has no telephone.

The Rolling Stones canceled three sold-out concerts in London and Wales because lead guitarist Keith Richards has an infected finger. Richards told reporters Friday he would ``absolutely'' be back on stage for tonight's concert at Wembley Stadium, but within hours doctors decided his finger needed more time to heal. The finger, pricked on the end of a guitar string, was injured during a show last weekend at Wembley. Doctors warned Richards that playing for two hours at Friday night's Wembley concert would cause serious damage. A concert Wednesday night in Cardiff, Wales, also was canceled because of the injury. The Wembley concerts, where sellout crowds of 72,000 had been expected, have been rescheduled for Aug. 24-25, tour publicist Jane Sen said. The tour is scheduled to end in August with concerts in Prague, Czechoslovakia, and East Berlin.

Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu stopped off in Colorado for a 1{-day vacation after a hectic week of meetings in Houston with leaders of industralized nations. Kaifu, who was to depart this afternoon, allowed 15 minutes for a media photo session on his arrival Friday at the posh Broadmoor Hotel. He then went for a brisk walk around the resort's private lake. Nine Greenpeace Action protesters from Boulder arrived too late for the prime minister's motorcade but stayed for an hour outside the hotel, waving banners and shouting for an end to Japanese involvement in felling rain forests and killing whales. Police said Kaifu planned a motor tour to Pikes Peak.

Democratic gubernatorial candidate Mike Hatch stopped in mid-sentence with his mouth agape when an aide at a news conference announced, ``Mike Hatch, you have a visitor,'' and Johnny Cash strode in. The country legend didn't introduce himself with the well-known, ``Hello. I'm Johnny Cash,'' but said he was happy to meet the candidate and added, ``It's nice to be in Minnesota.'' When asked whether he would endorse Hatch for governor, Cash said, ``I don't know. What's his name?'' Cash said he was passing through Duluth on his way to a concert when somebody asked whether he wanted to meet a candidate for governor.

DOC.HEAD: Party Urged to Rally Behind Bush _ Even on Taxes
With PM-Conservatives
DOC.TEXT: The Republican Party is urging its local leaders to rally behind President Bush as he considers tax increases that many in the GOP wish he would go back to opposing. The president's abrupt switch on taxes late last month caught most Republicans off guard, and left many questioning why Bush would abandon his campaign pledge with crucial 1990 elections just four months away. After initially lying low in the tax debate, party leaders came out swinging Friday, painting Bush's turnabout as a tough but bold move to help erase the federal deficit. Republican Illinois Gov. James Thompson said Bush ``had the courage to summon up the political will to do what was right for the country.'' But angry conservative leaders called a news conference in Washington to denounce Bush's retreat on taxes and other stands and threaten a possible re-election challenge. If the president ``stays in his present course, he will be challenged in 1992, almost certainly in the Republican primaries and certainly in the general election,'' said Howard Phillips, chairman of the Conservative Caucus. Bush has ``dealt a crippling blow to his own credibility,'' added David A. Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union. Despite their understandable trepidation over the possible political fallout, Thompson said it was no time for Republicans to back away from Bush. ``It is the obligation of Republicans, I think, to stand up for the president when the president is willing to take the political heat to stand up for the nation,'' the governor said. The GOP leaders, led by Vice President Dan Quayle, insisted the next move is up to Democrats. They said the Democrats must offer significant domestic spending cuts and budget-process reforms or watch Bush call off the bipartisan budget talks. ``We have put revenues on the table,'' Quayle said in a speech to the Republican National Committee's midyear meeting. ``Today, I call on the congressional Democrats to come forth with their proposed spending cuts. Their silence on this issue _ as usual _ is deafening.'' Quayle told the RNC members that Bush would not cut a deal favorable to Democrats. ``His position is simple,'' Quayle said: ``a good deal or no deal at all.'' If the Democrats don't make significant proposals soon, many Republicans believe Bush should walk out on the talks. Such a move won a ringing endorsement from Peggy Noonan, a former speechwriter for Reagan and Bush who wrote Bush's ``read my lips: no new taxes'' pledge. Noonan, who is no longer involved in party affairs, won applause from the RNC when she suggested Bush should ``push himself away from the table and cut himself a walking stick'' unless Democrats offer sizable spending cuts. ``I truly believe we must not lose the tax issue,'' she said. ``There is no more potent issue than this.''

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Agrees to Cut Service by Three Months
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's governing coalition has agreed to cut the country's obligatory military service from 15 months to 12 months. Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg told reporters on Friday that a measure would be submitted to lawmakers in September. It would affect all recruits drafted after October 1989, he said. The decision was expected to reduce the size of the West German military by 35,000. During last week's NATO summit, the West Germans promised to announce by the fall their plans for troop cutbacks in a united German military. The potential size of a united German army has been one of Moscow's concerns as German unification approaches. West Germany has about 465,000 active-duty troops and East Germany about 100,000.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptian Mummies To Be Checked For AIDS-Type Viruses
DOC.TEXT: Dutch researchers say they will search for traces of AIDS-type viruses in ancient Egyptian mummies by studying their genetic makeup. The research team will use a recently developed cloning process to extract genetic chains from samples of skin and bone tissue taken from mummified humans and animals. ``The idea will be to look for DNA sequences comparable to the sequence left by AIDS infection,'' Dr. Jan Gelen, a biochemist working on the research team, said Friday. The tissue analyses are scheduled to begin early next year. ``It is possible that the AIDS virus could have existed for thousands of years in another non-dangerous form,'' said Gelen.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0638, AM-BRF--Green Cards, on Wednesday under a Paris dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Wednesday that the ``green cards'' issued to aliens living in the United States henceforth will be made in France. Thomson-CSF, a major French manufacturer of military equipment, has been selected by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service to provide the technology for producing a new generation of cards. The cards themselves will continue to be made in Arlington, Texas, the company said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Tests Outside TV Cameras on Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: A jumbo jet will be fitted with closed-circuit television cameras on its tail fin and belly to test whether they would enhance safety, the government says. The British Airways Boeing 747's tailfin camera will monitor the length of the aircraft, and another on the underside of the fuselage will allow the crew to view the plane's undercarriage and flaps, the government said Friday. The use of external cameras was recommended by Britain's Air Accidents Investigation Branch in its preliminary report into an accident in January 1989 that killed 47 people. In the accident, the British Midland Boeing 737's left engine was on fire but the flight crew shut down the other one. The crew was unable to see either engine from the cockpit. The trial, being carried out with the Civil Aviation Authority, is expected to last three months.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Nears Wrap-up of Case Against D.C. Mayor
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution in Marion Barry's trial is nearing the end of its case and the mayor's lawyers say they plan an extensive defense that could last nearly two weeks. Ten to 15 witnesses will appear on Barry's behalf at his cocaine and perjury trial, defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy said Friday. He said the testimony is ``going to be full of thrills and surprises.'' It's not been decided whether Barry will take the witness stand in his own defense, but the mayor ``is champing at the bit'' to testify, Mundy told reporters. The government began presenting its case June 19 and is expected to finish Tuesday when the trial resumes. Its remaining witnesses are two friends of the mayor, Bettye Smith and Doris Crenshaw. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said he anticipates the defense case could take the trial into the last full week of July. On Friday, a longtime friend of the mayor, Darrell Sabbs, said his recollections of the timing of cocaine use with the mayor were heavily influenced by the FBI and prosecutors. Sabbs, who was reluctantly testifying for the prosecution, said he used cocaine with Barry five times between 1986 and 1989. But he said he has great difficulty remembering the years of the alleged use. Sabbs said he was ``under intense pressure by the government to testify.'' Mundy suggested to Sabbs that he had been told by the FBI regarding certain details of his alleged cocaine use with the mayor, ``It had to be this way.'' ``Yes,'' Sabbs replied. ``That happened repeatedly,'' said Mundy. ``It happened quite a few times,'' Sabbs agreed. ``You have difficulty with events'' and it's ``difficult to say with specificity'' when, where and what occurred, Mundy said at one point. ``It's been hard, yes sir,'' Sabbs responded. He said, ``The criminality and the politics have been so intense in this case'' that ``my responses only reflected the ... stress I was under.'' Sabbs told the FBI in March that he snorted cocaine with the mayor at a restaurant in 1989. In May, he told the FBI it had taken place a year earlier. He then changed it back to 1989 when he testified before a federal grand jury. He settled on 1987 when he testified Thursday at Barry's trial, after prosecutors showed Sabbs an invitation to his own birthday party at the restaurant. He said, however, that he had birthday parties at the restaurant twice and now thinks Barry's appearance was at the one in 1987. ``I am very confused ... it leaves me very baffled,'' said Sabbs. Barry is charged with 10 counts of possessing cocaine, one count of conspiracy and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about drug use. Cesar Gaviria, the president-elect of Colombia, said in an interview in today's editions of The Washington Post that if Barry were not convicted, ``a lot of damage'' would be done to his embattled country's war on druglords. ``We are on the front lines. We are losing so many lives, confronting terrorism and bombings, fighting the narco-traffickers,'' Gaviria told the newspaper. ``To see a person who has been mayor, who has been a very important person in this country and consumes drugs and (he) doesn't have any sanctions, we would have a lot of damage in Colombian opinion ....'' Barry's press secretary, Lurma Rackley, said the mayor would have no comment on Gaviria's remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Politicians Give Census Low Marks for Accuracy
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau's claim that it has counted 99.5 percent of all U.S. households on its master list does not mean the census will be accurate, two lawmakers say. The claim ``is as nonsensical as a little kid saying his room is all clean after he has shoved all of his clothes and toys in the closet and closes the door,'' Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., said Friday. Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., agreed. ``When it is declared that a city, a county, has been 100 percent enumerated, that simply means that all the known residences have been heard from,'' Moynihan said. ``... There will always be some missing in the count.'' The criticism came at a Senate Governmental Affairs Committee hearing on the status of the headcount and the nomination of Barbara Everitt Bryant to be director of the Bureau of the Census. Schumer contended that the 1990 census has been riddled with inaccuracies and omissions that will render it the worst national head count in U.S. history. ``The magnitude of the (Census) Bureau's mission does not excuse it from the sorts of logistical and bureaucratic gaffes we have witnessed over the past few months,'' Schumer testified. But Bryant, who has been acting Census Bureau director for seven months, stressed that the tally isn't finished and ``the fat lady has not sung.'' ``This has been a well-planned census, despite what some detractors said,'' she said. Schumer ticked off a list of problems, including the fact that at least 18 percent of New York City's households did not receive forms because the bureau's mailing lists were so bad. However, Rep. Tom Sawyer, D-Ohio, who chairs the House Post Office subcommittee on census and population, declined to call the census a failure. ``I don't believe either that the Census Bureau has failed to execute the best census it could,'' he said. ``But what I am prepared to say at this juncture is that the design of the census appears inadequate to measure a society as diverse and complex as ours.'' Officials from the General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, agreed that the 1990 census presented unusual challenges. L. Nye Stevens, director of the GAO's business operations issues department, pointed to a lower-than-expected response rate to mailed questionnaires, staffing problems and money shortages. ``GAO believes that the 1990 census experience demonstrates the need for fundamental rethinking of how the 2000 and future censuses should be taken,'' he testified. New York City and several other large urban centers have gone to court to force the Commerce Department to statistically adjust the census for an expected undercount. Such methodology now exists, Moynihan said, but the Commerce Department overruled the Census Bureau's plans to use it. ``It is on the edge of scandal,'' he added. ``They said do not do what was clearly a constitutional responsibility.'' New York Mayor David N. Dinkins said the Commerce Department's reluctance to adjust for an undercount is politically motivated. ``I can find no other rationale to which to assign this decision except political consideration,'' he said. Dinkins asked the committee to make sure that Bryant and the Census Bureau live up to the court-mandated agreement to make an adjustment decision no later than July 15, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Government Announces Water-Saving Measures As Capital's Supplies Dwindle
DOC.TEXT: The government has announced emergency water-saving measures and says it will use supertankers to transport the precious commodity to cope with the capital's worst shortage in a century. Steps announced Friday also include drilling for fresh supplies, swiftly repairing a damaged pipe network, and diverting a river in central Greece to a reservoir that supplies Athens. Water rates were raised drastically earlier this year, resulting in a 15 percent drop in consumption, authorities said. In the future, consumers who reduce their rate of water consumption are to be charged lower rates, and those who use more will pay higher rates. The capital's water utility company says its reserves are expected to last until early November, when the rainy season usually begins.

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Says Army to Help Clean up Nuclear Arms Plants
With PM-Hanford-Cancer Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department says it recruited the Army Corps of Engineers to help clean up environmental damage at federal nuclear weapons plants. ``The Corps of Engineers has many significant skills that can help us in our waste cleanup program,'' Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said in announcing Friday that his department had signed an agreement with the corps. Among the work to be provided by the corps is management services to Energy Department headquarters, technical assistance in planning and building waste cleanup projects at specific weapons sites and preparing cost estimates. Cathy Kaliniak, a department spokeswoman, said the corps would be involved in helping clean up the Hanford nuclear weapons plant in south-central Washington state, which is the most contaminated of the 17 major weapons plants. She said it had not been determined where else it might be involved. Watkins said the deal, signed late Thursday, is ``a very important step'' toward restoring the environment at the weapons plants, which operated for decades with no outside oversight. The full cleanup effort is expected to take more than 30 years and cost more than $100 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Containing Blazes in California, Oregon, Yellowstone Park
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CLARIFY. Pick up 3rd graf, `Earlier Friday ...'
DOC.TEXT: Humidity helped firefighters conquer a 6,500-acre brushfire started by a teen-ager's model rocket in a California state park, but a blaze in central Oregon broke its lines and expanded Friday. The Oregon fire, contained earlier in the week, grew to more than 1,500 acres, said Doug Decker of the Oregon Department of Forestry. Earlier Friday brought a break from lightning storms that ignited the blaze six miles southeast of Sisters, Ore. The fire had been contained at 600 acres Thursday night, said Jim Fisher, another department spokesman. At least six nearby homes were not in immediate danger. More firefighters will be added to the crew of 100 that had been battling the blaze, Decker said. Lightning storms this week started a total of 300 fires around Oregon, Fisher said. California's fire started Thursday in Chino Hills State Park, 40 miles southeast of Los Angeles, but it was fully surrounded Friday afternoon, said fire spokeswoman Maria Sobol. ``At this point it's not going anywhere. If weather conditions stay the same, it looks pretty good,'' she said. A lack of wind as well as moisture in the air aided the 700 firefighters. A 15-year-old Yorba Linda boy was arrested for investigation of unlawful use of a model rocket. It is illegal for a minor to use such rockets without supervision. The teen, released to his family, told officials the rocket malfunctioned and crashed into the dry brush. He tried to stamp the fire out, suffering minor burns to his leg, then called 911. In Wyoming, more than 80 firefighters, aided by fire retardant drops by air tankers, battled flames Friday from Yellowstone National Park's 12th fire of the year. It was only the second fire, however, to grow larger than two acres. The first, a 220-acre fire, was contained Monday. In Washington state, U.S. Forest Service spokesman Ron Dehart said most of the 55 small lightning fires in the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest have either been put out or were under attack. Totaling less than 60 acres, they were scattered in dozens of remote areas in eastern Snohomish, Skagit and King counties, he said. More than 30 lightning-sparked fires, ranging from small spots to 100 acres, were burning Friday in the rugged 3,000-foot to 7,000-foot slopes of the eastern Cascades, in the Wenatchee National Forest.

DOC.HEAD: Reserve Officers' Training Corps Units in 27 States To Close
DOC.TEXT: The Army is closing 50 college ROTC units in 27 states as part of a broad plan to shrink the service. The shutdowns, effective at the end of the 1990-91 academic year, will affect students at colleges and universities primarily in the Northeast and Midwest that have small numbers of cadets. G. Kim Wincup, assistant Army secretary for manpower and reserve affairs, said Friday that closing the Reserve Officers' Training Corps units was deemed necessary to cut the Army's overall size by 20 percent over the next five years. ``It's a pretty painful process for the Army,'' he said. ``We just need fewer lieutenants to come on active duty.'' Wincup said the Army also faces increasing budget pressures as Congress tries to reshape the nation's defenses in line with a collapsing Soviet-bloc military threat. The elimination of 50 ROTC units will save the Army about $23 million a year, Wincup said, and will cost the jobs of 740 Army personnel involved in the programs. He said he could not estimate how many cadets would be affected, but he said the Army's aim was to reduce the total number of graduating ROTC cadets to about 6,000 a year from about 7,800. After the 50 ROTC units are closed, the Army will have 363 units left in 50 states and the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and Guam. Eleven units were closed earlier this year. Wincup said cadets who are in one of the units to be closed next year but not scheduled to graduate by then will be guaranteed a place in an ROTC program on a nearby campus only if they are on a scholarship. Others wishing to continue in a program will have to arrange their own transfers, he said.
