DOC.TEXT: Lois Moran Young, a star of silent films who was known through much of her career as Lois Moran, died Friday at age 81. She died at the Kachina Point Health Center, a nursing home. The actress made more than two dozen movies, including ``Reckless Lady,'' ``The Road to Mandalay,'' ``Don't Marry,'' ``Mammy'' and ``The Men in Her Life.'' Mrs. Young made her first film at 14 and gained fame the following year when she starred with Ronald Colman in Samuel Goldwyn's ``Stella Dallas.'' She also sang for four years in the musical productions ``Of Thee I Sing'' and ``Let 'em Eat Cake'' and co-starred with Robert Preston in the television series ``Waterfront.'' F. Scott Fitzgerald reportedly based the character Rosemary in his novel ``Tender is the Night'' on Mrs. Young

DOC.HEAD: Explosion At Hotel Kills Black Worker
DOC.TEXT: A black worker was killed today in the bombing of a hotel frequented mostly by whites, police said. Police said there also was an explosion this morning at the suburban Johannesburg home of a reported right-wing white activist. No one was injured, police said. Police spokesman Lt. Peter du Preez said commercial explosives were used in the blast at the Will Smith Hotel in Florida, a suburb of Johannesburg. No one claimed responsibility and there was no immediate evidence the attack was politically motivated, police and the hotel owners said. Right-wing whites have claimed responsibility for a recent spate of bombings aimed at blacks and at whites who oppose apartheid, but the latest attack did not appear to fit the pattern. Florida is a middle-class and working-class area and most of the whites tend to be relatively conservative. The blast caused relatively minor damage, according to police and hotel owners. The slain man was a waiter in the hotel bar. There were about 130 patrons at the bar at the time of the blast, all of them white, said Rod Rodrigues, one of the owners. The other explosion was at the home of Hans Binneman, whom the independent South African Press Association described as a member of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement. It quoted police as saying he recently was detained for questioning about bombings in Johannesburg. Police say they suspect right-wing whites in the recent attacks and nine have been detained for questioning, but no one has been charged. Right-wing whites have vowed to resist President F.W. de Klerk's plans to dismantle apartheid and share power with the 30 million black majority. The African National Congress, the leading black opposition group, supports a guerrilla campaign against the government, but major attacks have ceased in recent months.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Plans New Effort to Chase Away Homeless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to RECAST, clarifying that Manhattan only part of 30-mile route, and to delete redundant `trip' in 4th graf. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `There's really...'.
DOC.TEXT: The city Transit Authority is making a new push to get rid of derelicts, drifters and displaced who use the country's biggest subway system as a place to sleep. Beginning Sunday, police will force all passengers to get off the A train when it arrives at the northern end of its 30-mile route, which includes the entire length of Manhattan. Anyone who balks will be physically removed, officials said. The A-train trip takes about 1{ hours, making it especially attractive to people who use the subways, which run 24 hours a day, as a place to sleep. ``There's really no problem with sleeping on the trains but we can't allow people to sprawl out and take up several seats,'' said Jared Lebow, a Transit Authority spokesman. He said a worse problem is the behavior of some homeless people when they are awakened at the final stop, a station where subway cars are cleaned and made ready for the return trip. ``Some of them get pretty upset when the workers try to get them to move. Some of our people have been hit, kicked and even spit on,'' Lebow said. The new policy follows a crackdown in early June aimed at removing hundreds of panhandlers and homeless people from the subways and the city's two major rail terminals, Grand Central Terminal and Penn Station. The new effort will be extended next month to another of the city's subway routes, the E train. The Transit Authority said workers from outreach programs will assist any homeless people who want to go to shelters. As with the earlier campaign to displace the displaced from Grand Central and Penn stations, the latest move prompted a sharp reaction from advocates for the homeless. ``When are they going to learn? Moving homeless people from one area to another accomplishes nothing,'' said Mary Brosnahan, director of the Coalition for the Homeless. ``When is somebody going to stop playing the shell game and work on real solutions to the problem?''

DOC.HEAD: Irish Envoy Discusses Hostages With Syrian Intelligence Officer
DOC.TEXT: Irish envoy Adrian McDaid met today with a Syrian intelligence officer in an effort to gain some information on the hoped-for release of Irish hostage Brian Keenan. McDaid, first secretary of the Irish Embassy in Baghdad, which also oversees Irish affairs in Lebanon, was scheduled to meet later with Prime Minister Salim Hoss. The results of the meeting between McDaid and Syrian Brig. Ali Hammoud were unclear. Hammoud is in charge of security in west Beirut. A source at the Irish consulate, speaking on condition of anonymity, said McDaid was ``trying to find out from Brigadier Hammoud whether the Syrians had any information on the hostage release.'' He refused to elaborate. The Irish diplomat flew to Lebanon Thursday in an effort to verify a report by Iran's official news agency that a European hostage held in Lebanon would be released soon. The report, issued by the Islamic Republic News Agency last week, did not identify the hostage to be freed. But sources close to the command of Syria's 40,000 troops in Lebanon said it would be Keenan. McDaid visited the Iranian news agency's west Beirut office on Friday to inquire about the agency's sources. IRNA's resident correspondent Mussayeb Naimi said: ``We stressed that our sources are reliable and we explained to Mr. McDaid that the hostage to be released will probably be a European national.'' ``He asked us about the reports that said Keenan will be released and we explained to him that our report did not name the hostage,'' Naimi added. The 16 Western hostages held mainly by pro-Iranian underground Shiite factions are Keenan, six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. Keenan, an English language teacher from Belfast, was kidnapped in west Beirut April 11, 1986, as he walked to the American University of Beirut, where he worked.

DOC.HEAD: State of the Art Exhibit Opens in Chicago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Since Indeck...', and 15th graf, `The rest..', to fix typos in `first'; `on.'
DOC.TEXT: Also in Saturday AMs report.

Artists are expressing themselves in a new way with modern technology, but they've got to get their fax right. ``Artists love new toys, to experiment, to look for new visual results,'' said Karen Indeck, co-curator of the University of Illinois' Faxart exhibit. ``Visual art is about images, and it's an incredible use of a new technology to create these images.'' Co-sponsored by University of Illinois' School of Art and the School of the Art Institute, Faxart features the work of their alumni and other artists worldwide and is entirely composed of work transmitted by fascimile machine. On July 2, a fax machine was activated at Gallery 400, an old bra and girdle factory converted into a gallery. Ever since, the phone has been ringing with entries. Some artists redialed more than five hours before getting through. Beyond its novelty, another appeal of fax art to artists is its short-lived quality. Judith Kitzes, an Evanston-based artist, submitted a piece consisting only of the words ``Learn to Live with Ambiguity.'' The computer-generated sentence is repeated 108 times on 10 sheets of paper. ``I like the idea that I wrote one sentence, repeated it, the original in the computer does not exist, the original on paper I destroyed after faxing it, and the work of art _ the fax _ will fade,'' she said. ``It's a contradiction of what we expect art to be _ this precious thing. It really isn't. That's something that appeals to my sense of the bizarre: self-destructive art.'' The transient, informal nature of the medium also appealed to Indeck and co-curator Mary Min, who have been busily pinning and taping landscapes, abstracts and portraits to the walls and columns at Gallery 400. Since Indeck and Min plugged in a donated fax machine and loaded the first roll of paper, about 900 artworks have been received. The show is the first major exhibit featuring only fax art, its curators said. David Hockney's 144-sheet tennis match, faxed from California to a gallery in Saltaire, England, in November, is one of the first fax art pieces ever exhibited. So far, Indeck and Min have used 1,600 pushpins and countless rolls of double-sided tape to hang about 300 works, some from as far away as Spain and the Netherlands. The rest lie in piles on the floor. On Friday _ just hours before the exhibit was to open to the public _ an uninterrupted stream of works still flowed from the fax machine while an assistant sorted and filed the entries. Min said the challenge of creating images that would have an impact even after being faxed _ and the speed by which those images could be transmitted worldwide _ sparked her curiosity. ``You finish something, you send it out, and you get a response _ it's an artist's dream,'' said Min, a Chicago-based neon artist. ``And when the show's over, poof! It's gone.'' Images created on the thermal paper used in fax machines last about six months _ less if they're exposed to sunlight or bright artificial illumination. Fax art can be carefully preserved by de-acidifying the paper, but not the works exhibited at Faxart. Min said the pieces will be recycled when the show closes Aug. 17. So when talk arose about whether to put the artwork up for sale, it really was just in jest. Said Chicago artist Julie Richman: ``How would you sell this? Would someone with a fax machine say, `I want to buy this,' and then I would fax it?''

DOC.HEAD: Precede VIENNA
First Trainload of Albanians Arrives in West Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD refugees arriving in Heidelberg, CHANGE byline; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ATH1, BRI5
DOC.TEXT: The first of more than 3,000 Albanian refugees arrived in West Germany by train today, joyously waving their hands in victory as they savored their new freedom. About 125 Albanians reached southern Heidelberg aboard a special West German train that left Basel, Switzerland, after a brief stopover en route from Italy. ``There was no way to live,'' Avni Azizi, a 23-year-old Albanian tailor said of his hard-line Communist homeland. ``We all think that, at the most, in one year the whole Albanian people will be free.'' The refugees began crowding into foreign embassies in Tirana two weeks ago, seeking to flee Albania, which has resisted the kinds of sweeping democratic reforms that radically altered other East European countries since last fall. About 4,500 Albanians were evacuated in a sealift across the Adriatic Sea to Brindisi, Italy, early Friday. Today, 56 refugees sheltered in the Polish Embassy in the Albanian capital reached Warsaw by plane and were taken to an army facility northwest of the city. Another 39 Albanian refugees, including six women and two children, arrived in Budapest, Hungary, by plane and were sent to a refugee camp in the Buda hills, near the capital, according to news reports. On the same plane were five Albanians who took refuge at the Bulgarian Embassy. They departed Budapest for the Bulgarian capital of Sofia, Budapest radio said. Most of the refugees were reported to want to emigrate to Western Europe or the United States where they have relatives and friends, the radio said. The French Foreign Ministry announced in a communique that the ferry Orient Star, carrying 544 Albanians, will dock at Marseille on Sunday. A special train will transport 514 to reception centers near Reims and they will then be bused to reception centers in Mourmelon, Creil and Emance. The remaining 30 will be taken to centers at Perigueux and St. Astier in the Dordogne region of southwestern France. The ship had been scheduled to arrive in Marseille today, but fell behind schedule when a pregnant woman, Dirianda Daja, 21, became ill and had to be evacuated to Italy, Agence-France Presse said. Four ships chartered by the West German, Italian and French governments had picked up the 4,500 Albanians in the Albaninan port of Durres early Friday under an agreement worked out with United Nations mediation. Before Albanian authorities sealed off the embassy compounds, asylum-seekers scrambled up embassy walls and pushed their way through gates, sometimes braving police gunfire. The Albanian government agreed to let the refugees leave the country after supplies of food and medicine in the embassies ran low and hygienic conditions deteriorated. Three West German trains were sent to Italy to collect the 3,200 Albanians who sought refuge in the West German Embassy in Tirana. In Basel, they boarded smaller trains taking them to 14 towns in West Germany. Those arriving in Heidelberg, 60 miles south of Frankfurt, were the first to reach their destination. They arrived tired after a seven-hour boat journey to Brindisi and 26-hour train ride to West Germany, but they said they were elated by the prospect of a new life. Enkeo Halili, a 24-year-old mechanic, said: ``We are leaving our country because we don't want these Communists. We are young ... we are poor. We've never even seen a discotheque.'' The German Red Cross said 10 of the 125 refugees were sick and would be taken to hospitals. Carl Bauer, a Red Cross spokesman in Bonn, said they were suffering from fever, diarrhea and weakness. Other Albanians were taken to a former clinic in Heidelberg that until recently housed East German refugees. A defection of tens of thousands of East Germans last fall fueled the downfall of that nation's hard-line Communist government. The Albanian government introduced limited reforms last year, including some religious freedom and travel abroad, which Albanians were not permitted for 45 years. On Friday, about 100,000 people rallied in the Albanian capital of Tirana in support of the Communist leadership, the state ATA news agency reported. The rally was organized in Skanderbeg Square, close to the diplomatic community where the refugees began seeking asylum on June 28. Xhelil Gjoni, a member of the party's policy-making Politburo, told the rally that ``Albania and its people's power are unshaken by degenerate people who abandon their homeland or by anyone else,'' said a Tirana Radio broadcast, monitored in London.

DOC.HEAD: American Woman Seriously Injured During Running of The Bulls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with hometown, quotes; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Pamplona
DOC.TEXT: A young American, the first woman known to be injured in the running of the bulls, suffered a fractured skull today on the final day of the weeklong San Fermin festival, a hospital spokesman said. Stephanie Kern, 21, was being treated at the emergency room of Navarre Hospital after she was knocked down by a bull during the run at the festival made famous by author Ernest Hemingway, the spokesman said. He said Ms. Kern, of Myrtle Beach, S.C., was in serious condition. ``She wanted to do it so badly. I support her in what she wants to do, which might have been a mistake this time,'' said the injured woman's mother, Hannah Kern of Clinchport, Va. ``Everybody told me how safe it was.'' Ms. Kern, who will be a senior at Coastal College in Conway, S.C., and her mother arrived in Pamplona July 11. She is the first woman known to have been injured in the running of the bulls, officials said. Although women now are allowed to participate, few are ever seen among the dozens of mostly young men who test their bravery by running ahead of or alongside the bulls, which are later killed at evening bullfights. Mrs. Kern said her daughter had been racing ahead of the six bulls in a pack of people when the group suddenly surged forward. When she looked ahead to check her footing, a bull butted her with his head, and caught her torso inside his horns. The force of the impact sent her sprawling head first to the cobblestone street, Mrs. Kern said. Five other people were treated at area hospitals after being less seriously injured during the 2{-minute run with the bulls along the half-mile route from the corrals to the city bullring. The daily runs are the highlight of the weeklong festival, which was the setting for Hemingway's novel ``The Sun Also Rises'' and attracts thousands of tourists from around the world. According to city records, bulls have gored to death 52 people during the festival, which has been held continuously since 1591.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze and Woerner Hold Talks on Unification of Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Foreign Minister...' to CORRECT that Woerner is secretary general sted general secretary. Pickup pvs 3rd graf, `At the...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet foreign minister and the head of NATO began talks today on how to resolve military and political problems related to German unification, the official Tass news agency said. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Manfred Woerner, secretary general of the Western military alliance, were also expected to discuss the NATO summit held in London earlier this month. At the summit, alliance leaders agreed on a new strategy and proposed a non-aggression declaration to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Woerner was to meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Kremlin where he is likely to extend the official invitation for the Soviet leader to visit the Brussels headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Woerner, who was West German Defense Minister from 1982-88 in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government, is also likely to outline the implications of German unification during meetings with Soviet officials. The Kremlin, which still has an estimated 380,000 troops in former Communist East Germany, so far has declined to agree to a united Germany's membership in NATO. The questions of Germany's military and political obligations are being worked out in the framework of ``two-plus-four'' talks between the two Germanies and four World War II allies _ the United States, France, Great Britain and the Soviet Union. Sessions of those talks have already been held in Bonn and East Berlin and a further round is expected in Moscow early this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Two Cuban Refugees Leave Czechoslovak Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Two of the 14 Cubans who sought refuge in Czechoslovakia's embassy in Havana earlier this week have left the mission, the Foreign Ministry said today. According to a report carried by the state CTK news agency, one refugee left without notifying the embassy and the other asked to be released. The two apparently left without explanation. ``They left Friday afternoon, sometime between 4 and 4:30 p.m. local time,'' said Marcel Cintalan, a Foreign Ministry official. ``We don`t know why. They did not give any reasons.'' A senior official said Friday that Czechoslovakia would not turn the Cuban refugees in the Havana embassy over to authorities and that Prague was prepared for long and complicated talks over their fate. Three other asylum-seekers have sought refuge in Spain's Havana embassy. The Czechoslovak deputy foreign minister, Lubos Dobrovsky, met with Cuban Ambassador Mario Rodriguez Martinez Friday and asked Cuba to grant the refugees free passage. Dobrovsky also met with senior Soviet, West German and Italian diplomats to seek their help in resolving the situation. Tension has been growing between the two former Communist allies since a democratic revolution swept Czechoslovakia's Communist rulers from power last winter. Earlier this week, Prague said it suspected the influx of Cuban refugees might be a deliberate provocation by Havana to underline the growing strain between the nations.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Seal Hunt Plan Dropped in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: A businessman has dropped plans to kill 30,000 South African seals, following protests by international animal rights activists, a government official said Saturday. The businessman, Hsu Hsien-i, had received approval from South Africa to kill 25,000 seal cubs for processing as dog food. He was also to cull 5,000 adult male seals, whose genitals are prized as aphrodisiacs in the Far East. But after protests, South Africa this month temporarily suspended plans for the seal kill. Hsu has since decided to abandon the project, acccording to Foreign Ministry spokesman, Huang Hsin-pi. He said the Foreign Ministry recently asked Hsu to reconsider plans to kill the seal cubs because of the international outcry. Some protesters had threatened to boycott Taiwanese products. Many countries have outlawed the killing of seals. South Africa initially defended the seal culling project, saying the country's 1.2 million seals ate huge quanties of fish and could damage the fishing industry.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Barry Behavior Fits Pattern of Substance Abuser
DOC.TEXT: On Dec. 22, 1988, Mayor Marion Barry rushed his aides through a session on the city budget and then left hurriedly, saying he needed to attend a funeral. But according to testimony in Barry's drug and perjury trial, the mayor first drove that day to the hotel room of an acquaintance, drug dealer Charles Lewis. Lewis has said in court that Barry presented him with a crack cocaine pipe and the two men tested it. The events of that afternoon provide a glimpse into the life of a man whose official duties included grappling publicly with the difficulties of a large urban city, while _ according to numerous witnesses at the trial _ routinely using illegal drugs in private. Medical experts say juggling such activities would be difficult, but not impossible, and that substance abusers can hide their problems from close associates. But they pay a price. ``The bottom line is that in policy-making jobs, when you talk about alcohol and drugs, there's no question that they will have an effect on job performance,'' said Dr. Michael Stoil of the Washington-area chapter of Council on Alcohol and Drug Abuse. ``Normally, you see the effect mostly with attention span and concentration.'' ``Studies of alcoholism, in particular, generally suggest that work is the last thing to go,'' said Dr. Marc Hertzman, a George Washington University psychiatry professor who studies the effects of substance abuse. ``When all else _ marriage, family life _ is gone, most people can still carry on effectively enough so that their associates and superiors do not suspect a problem,'' Hertzman said in an interview last week. Barry has pleaded innocent to all charges, although he has admitted using cocaine in what he says was an FBI entrapment when he was arrested last Jan. 18 during a sting operation at a Washington hotel. So far in the trial, which resumes Tuesday, eight prosecution witnesses have testified that they saw Barry use drugs, including cocaine, crack cocaine, marijuana and opium, with the first such allegation dating to 1985. One witness, Rasheeda Moore, testified that she and the mayor used drugs more than 100 times together. Following his arrest, Barry spent seven weeks in Florida and South Carolina substance abuse treatment programs. He has said he was treated for addictions to alcohol and two prescription medicines. The experts' experience that a substance abuser can continue to work, even though impaired, conforms with the recollections of Barry's top advisers. ``He seemed very distracted, unfocused,'' said one top Barry aide in recalling the December 1988 meeting on the city budget. ``He was in a real hurry to leave, and here we were talking about the possibility of a budget deficit. He did not give his full time and attention to the meeting,'' the aide said. Even before that day in 1988, the mayor's own aides had begun a quiet surveillance of their own, keeping track of how many morning meetings Barry missed and whether he was paying attention in the ones he did attend. ``Something was wrong,'' one aide said. ``He had always been so sharp, but he just wasn't anymore.'' ``It was like with families of alcoholics,'' said another top aide. ``We'd meet with him, come out and ask each other, `Well, how did he look today?' The aides spoke only on condition that their names not be used. By the fall of 1989 many of Barry's top assistants had concluded privately that the mayor had a substance abuse problem. They recall being startled in November 1989 when Barry used a city cabinet meeting to give a speech on the dangers of drug abuse and then introduce seven recovering addicts who discussed their problems. ``At the end of the meeting, in front of all 50 of us, the mayor asked one of them what cocaine felt like,'' said one cabinet member who was there. And at the next month's cabinet meeting _ less than a month before his arrest in the sting operation _ Barry invited two doctors to address the group on the medical effects of drug abuse. ``It was almost like he was going through a cathartic experience, crying out for help, and dragging us along,'' said another cabinet member, who also spoke only on condition of anonymity. ``Many of us were ignorant about drugs, and the mayor certainly cast himself in that camp.'' One drug counselor says Barry's behavior fits a well-known pattern. ``Generally speaking, that is part of the manipulation that goes on in a person's mind to deny the use _ to cover their tracks with other people,'' says Jill Wiedemann-West, a drug counselor with Hazelden Services Inc. ``Part of (the) denial is to make people believe you are not in any way, shape or form involved in drugs.''

DOC.HEAD: Floods, Mudslides Kill At Least 21 People, 31 Missing
DOC.TEXT: Flooding and mudslides caused by three days of heavy rains killed 21 people and left 31 missing in two provinces, the official China Daily newspaper said Saturday. Floodwaters inundated Beixu village in northern Shanxi province, leaving at least 14 people dead and five missing, the paper said. Seven people were killed and 26 missing in mudslides in Liangshan prefecture, southwestern Sichuan province, it said. Heavy rain and hail began pounding Shanxi at midnight Wednesday, and nearly 3 inches of rain fell in less than an hour, the report said. Protective dams around Beixu village collapsed, allowing floodwaters to rush through. Many villages in Shanxi are located in deep gullies caused by centuries of erosion, and are prone to flooding.

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Has Not Solved All Eastern Europe's Problems
DOC.TEXT: Millions of East Europeans expected the tide of democracy that swept the Communists from power last year to solve all their problems. It hasn't, and discontent is spreading. Janos Lampert, a 32-year-old electrician in Budapest, Hungary, was an avid supporter of the democracy movement. Three months after democratic elections gave Hungary its first non-Communist government in four decades, he still moonlights to support his wife and two children. Laid up after an accident, Lampert watched democracy at work _ live televised Parliament sessions. ``Disgusting,'' he said. ``I just can't see those guys, yakking all day while the economy is in shambles.'' Problems in Budapest may differ from those in Bucharest, East Berlin, Prague, Sofia or Warsaw, but disappointment is widespread. Some East Europeans question whether the battle for democracy has really been won. Others are depressed by the long road to prosperity that lies ahead. Hungarians have been subjected to price increases, new taxes and business bankruptcies that produced unemployment. The mood is sullen. Many believe the new government of political neophytes is unequal to the task of improving conditions with a minimum of pain. For Hungarians thinking of starting a business, government permission takes up to three months. Inflation exceeded 30 percent in the first quarter, industrial production dropped more than 8 percent and an estimated 50,000 people were unemployed, compared with 3,200 a year ago. The foreign debt of $20.6 billion is the highest per capita in Eastern Europe. Decades of Communist mismanagement in Romania left many industries and services barely functioning, but there is enough to eat for the first time in a decade. In a country unused to even a trace of freedom, the meeting of basic needs appears to be reason for economic contentment. The political situation is less promising. Multiparty elections held May 20 were generally fair, but were preceded by campaign violence unequalled in the region. Many Romanians still fear and distrust the victorious National Salvation Front, whose leaders they consider Commmunist. The government's inauguration last month was preceded by violent attacks on government institutions and mob rule by miners answering a government appeal for help. ``After such a bloody riot, it is very easy to bring people back onto the streets,'' Adrian Severin, who is charged with introducing a market economy, said afterward. ``The hate in the people's soul was not at all consumed.'' Political turmoil also contributes to a sense of insecurity in Bulgaria, the only East European country where the ruling Communists won democratic elections. Threats of escalating strikes forced the resignation July 7 of President Petar Mladenov, a reform Communist, and protests continue by activists seeking a full reckoning with the past. Concern that a government hamstrung by protest would not be able to deal with pressing economic problems added to the pessimism in Bulgaria. It has had to suspend payments of all but interest on the $10 billion debt. An estimated 60 percent of industry is unprofitable and unemployment is growing. Nowhere does the connection between economic and political problems seem so clear as in Poland, where the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki won partially free elections more than a year ago. Stores are relatively well stocked and people appear to be managing, but workers have gone on strike over rising prices and wage controls. Mazowiecki's critics want to replace President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist leader, with Solidarity leader Lech Walesa. They say the people are less willing to make economic sacrifices when the president and many members of Parliament are Communist holdovers. In a speech to workers July 8, Walesa said: ``We were not prepared for ... the work that would come after the abolition of communism.'' Even Czechoslovaks, left with a relatively healthy economy, are having trouble with economic adjustments. Food prices were increased 25 percent on July 11. Rents and energy costs are scheduled to rise in the fall, followed by total price decontrol and accelerated conversion to private enterprise early next year. ``I don't know what I'll do if things go on like this,'' said pensioner Libuse Klementova. East Germans are assured of relatively quick prosperty through union with West Germany, but are bracing for short-term turmoil. One-third to more than one-half the country's 8,000 major enterprises are expected to go broke in a few months. Millions of people could lose their jobs and many people have predicted a ``hot autumn'' of strikes. With West Germany financing economic reform, officials say the situation will begin to improve next year.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels to Negotiate Release of Two Kidnapped Aid Workers
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels have agreed to negotiate the release of a kidnapped U.S. Peace Corps volunteer and a Japanese aid worker, a retired Roman Catholic bishop said. Members of a committee met today to discuss terms laid down by the rebels here on Negros island, 300 miles southeast of Manila. Retired Bishop Antonio Fortich said the offer and conditions for the release of Timothy Swanson and Fumio Mizuno were contained in a letter from Celso Magsilang, spokesman for the New People's Army on Negros. Rebels kidnapped Mizuno, 36, an official of the Organization for Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement, on May 29 and Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo., on June 13. Fortich said the letter was the first rebel confirmation they were holding the two. ``They said they are willing to surrender both of them, either separately or together,'' Fortich said. Fortich said rebel conditions included a three-day truce with the military. He said they also want soldiers excluded from the negotiating committee, and a representative of the International Red Cross, two doctors, the Filipino wives of the two captives, and members of the news media included in the talks. Fortich is also a member of the committee. Last month, the United States suspended its 21-year-old Peace Corps program in the Philippines and sent all volunteers home because of alleged rebel threats against staffers.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: she said.
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Rohde says every day since last July 19 is a gift. ``By all rights, I should have been dead almost a year ago,'' says the 40-year-old veterinarian from Marysville, Ohio. ``It's easier to find the silver lining in the clouds now. Life's irritations are a little easier to shrug off. What's there to get worked up about when you could be upside down in a burning airplane? ``Every time the sun comes up, I think how lucky I am to be able to see it,'' says Rohde. Now, when he flies, ``I look at the stewardesses and I look at the pilots and I wonder if it came crunch time if they would perform as well as the captain and flight crew on Flight 232.'' His two children worry, saying: ``You're not flying on a DC-10? Your plane better not crash.' I say, `They usually don't.' ''

Clifton Marshall, 45, of Ostrander, Ohio, works with Rohde and was with him on Flight 232. In the last moments before the crash, he wrote a goodbye letter to his family. Today he has no angry words, no hostile feelings. ``There are people who think all of the risks should be covered. They're more inclined to think that the world should be risk free. That ain't the way that it is. ... I take bigger risks everyday riding my bicycle to work,'' says Marshall.

Bruce Benham believes that walking away from Flight 232 was the second of two deliverances he's had in life. The first was his recovery from thyroid cancer in 1985. Now, after the crash, he's found a new appreciation for life. ``The first time I went skiing last winter the mountains and the snow seemed more beautiful. There is a certain exhilaration in surviving,'' the 38-year-old Denver restaurant executive says. ``I've become very health and safety conscious because the crash heightened my concern about not being here forever. I've lost 25 pounds in the last six months and I worked at it.''

William Robertson has composed a list of accomplishments and things he still wants to do in life. He already has checked off one item on his wish list: hot-air ballooning. The 48-year-old Amoco executive from Wheaton, Ill., has set a goal of visiting 20 to 25 foreign counties in the next 10 years and has shifted his priorities. ``I give more time to my family and friends and people I care about. In many cases, I'm more selfish with whom I choose to spend my time.''

Upton Rehnberg's frequent pains in his right hip are a physical reminder. There are emotional ones, too. ``I was (recently) talking to somebody about the crash, all of a sudden I was crying. ... It suddenly brought back a lot of the emotions that I felt.'' Rehnberg, who works for Sundstrand Corp., a manufacturer of aircraft components, suffered facial and arm burns when a fireball swept into the plane. He didn't return to his job until December, and hasn't been back on a DC-10. ``I'm working at becoming less of a workaholic. I'm spending a lot more time outdoors.'' Rehnberg, who lives in Rockford, Ill., also is struggling with another personal change _ divorce, which, he says, his wife partly attributes to consequences of the crash. The last year has been one of ``incredible turmoil, both externally and internally. ... This is just the beginning of a cycle of many, many changes. My life is never going to be the same.''

Jerry Schemmel has stayed in touch with the family of 1-year-old Sabrina Michaelson, the girl he ran back inside the burning plane to save. Sabrina, of West Chester, Ohio, had been thrown through the air and separated from her mother, father and two brothers. Her cries caught Schemmel's ear as he fled. ``I was tested a little bit, so that has made me feel better. If I'd heard the crying and not gone back into the plane I would have had terrible guilt feelings. But you'd be surprised how many people would have done what I did,'' says Schemmel, 30, of Denver. In the past year, Lori Michaelson, 36, has turned from survivor to crusader _ lobbying for mandatory infant seats on planes. ``I'm trying just to go on. ... Instead of going overboard and spoiling your kids, you try not to overcompensate in your life. ... ``You try to consciously focus on each day and realize how out of control your life is ... how rapidly things can change. You think you're creating your own destiny in your life and you're not,'' the mother of three says. Major disasters rehash all the hurt, she says. And even normal child's play can cause problems. ``The oddest things come out,'' she says. A child brought over a cap gun once and her son, Andrew, ``got really upset. He didn't want him to use it. It smelled like a burning airplane.'' And 23-month-old Sabrina? ``She's learned to talk ... and started walking. She has been running ever since.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Special Correspondent Tad Bartimus is the AP's Mountain States regional reporter, based in Denver. Sharon Cohen is the AP's Midwest regional reporter, based in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Vicar's Revenge: A Mailshot to Deter Junk Mail
DOC.TEXT: An English vicar is hitting back at the junk mail industry with offers of ``your very own timeshare room in the Mansion of Heaven.'' Rev. Robin Charles of the Church of the Holy Spirit in Etching Hill, northwest England, has been sending out a riposte to the worst offenders, telling them they ``have been exclusively selected'' to help repair his church. ``We would like to offer you a unique opportunity, only repeated once a week, to join our heavenly timeshare scheme. To take advantage of this exclusive offer just send a small donation for our building fund,'' it says. ``In return, you are assured your very own timeshare room in the Mansion of Heaven and if you reply within seven days we will send you _ totally free _ a personally designed blessing of your own choice. ``Just imagine, your very own blessing complete with one guaranteed place in salvation!'' The text of the offer appeared in Saturday's Daily Telegraph and was confirmed by Charles' wife, Thelma. The Telegraph quoted the vicar as saying he wanted the junk mailers ``to have a laugh and maybe dip into their pockets and send us a donation. We need 75,000 pounds ($135,000) to repair the church.'' He has sent two dozen letters, and received a single donation of $45. Charles was quoted as saying his annual intake of junk mail ``must be equal to about three Brazilian trees. Now the companies know what it's like to get some of it back. ``But I reckon that if one piece of paper stops them sending me 20 pieces then I've won.''

DOC.HEAD: Key Senators Urging Bush to Revamp Policy on Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Influential senators are joining an effort to persuade President Bush to revamp U.S. policy toward Cambodia, saying the current one could return the dreaded Khmer Rouge to power. In the draft of a letter to Bush, the group says ``the Khmer Rouge represents an unacceptable threat to the people of Cambodia, and that American policy should be based, first and foremost, upon preventing the return of the Khmer Rouge.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and a bipartisan group of 10 other senators suggest in the letter that Bush should open the door to contacts between the United States and the Vietnamese-backed Phnom Penh government of Hun Sen. They also ask Bush to implement a congressionally authorized aid program for children who are victims of the country's civil war and loosen restrictions on U.S. development and humanitarian aid to Cambodia. The letter, circulated for signatures last week, is the latest sign of growing congressional opposition to a decade-old policy which sends U.S. aid to a loose political coalition fighting the Hun Sen government. It has become increasingly clear that the Khmer Rouge, whose regime was responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians in the 1970s, could be indirectly riding the U.S. support back into power as the dominant member of the coalition. While the Bush administration insists that none of the U.S. aid is helping the communist rebel group, there is increasing restiveness on Capitol Hill. Last month the Senate Intelligence Committee voted to kill a covert aid program for the resistance, reportedly worth $10 million. The United States also has a $7 million program of overt, non-lethal aid to the resistance coalition. Those pressing for the policy change included Intelligence Committee Chairman David Boren, D-Okla., vice chairman William Cohen, R-Maine, and committee member John Danforth, R-Mo.; Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., and senior committee Republican Mark Hatfield of Oregon. Also included were Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., and committee members Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan.; and Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; as well as Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va., a past strong supporter of administration policy; and Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. The administration and its congressional supporters say the aid is important to keep alive an alternative political force that could vie for power if negotiations succeeded in bringing about elections. But the critics are not buying that. ``The president's policy in Cambodia is indefensible,'' Mitchell told reporters last week. ``It doesn't make any sense. How can we, the United States, which has already enacted into law a prohibition on aiding the Khmer Rouge, engage in a policy which does precisely that?'' He expressed hope that the letter from Capitol Hill would help strengthen those within the administration who are embarrassed about the U.S. stance. Mitchell and others, including Rep. Chet Atkins, D-Mass., have suggested that with Vietnam's withdrawal from Cambodia last year, the Khmer Rouge now represents a far greater threat. They believe U.S. Cambodia policy is a symptom of a larger Bush blind spot when it comes to China _ the Khmer Rouge's chief sponsor. ``It all goes back to China, the administration doesn't want to offend China,'' Mitchell said. ``We believe that American policy can and should more clearly and effectively help prevent future Khmer Rouge domination of Cambodia,'' stated the letter. The group asks that Bush ``clearly state that the United States will not support a negotiated solution that would give the Khmer Rouge a role in Cambodia's future or increase the likelihood of a Khmer Rouge military victory.'' And noting a promise by Hun Sen to hold U.N.-supervised elections, it expresses the ``hope that you will see value in opening up direct contacts with representatives of the regime in Phnom Penh.'' It also asks for a more thorough investigation into reports of military coordination between the non-communist resistance forces, including the U.S.-backed faction led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and the Khmer Rouge. And it asks for an end to U.S. support for any participation by the Khmer Rouge in Cambodian representation at the United Nations. ``Better an empty seat than one which bestows international legitimacy'' upon the forces of the infamous Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot, the letter contends.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Leaders Use Midyear Meeting To Launch Fall Offensive
DOC.TEXT: Republican leaders trying to get the party back on sure footing after a stretch of rocky road are setting out on a trusted course _ attack. It has been a tumultuous year for the GOP, beginning with a divisive debate over abortion in January and then the news in March that party Chairman Lee Atwater had a brain tumor. He has been sidelined ever since. More recently, Republicans have been on the defensive as Democrats try to blame them for the savings and loan crisis and GOP candidates try to cope with President Bush's abrupt abandonment of his ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge. But at a three-day meeting in Chicago that ended Saturday, the Republican National Committee resolved to go back on the offensive. ``Controlling the agenda is the way to continue winning,'' said Mary Matalin, Atwater's top deputy at the RNC. ``We somehow allowed ourselves to fall off of offense, but the message is clear now.'' A chorus of GOP leaders used both public and private sessions during the GOP's midyear meeting to urge Republicans at both the state and national level to be more aggressive. ``The obituaries are premature,'' Ed Rollins, head of the party's House campaign arm, told the group in a speech laced with blistering attacks on Democrats. From a lesser-known Republican, Mayor Sue Myrick of Charlotte, N.C., came a demand that Republicans at all levels stop trying to look and sound like Democrats. ``Far too many Republicans are not drifting but rather diving headlong into softened stands on such issues as abortion, flag burning and more taxes rather than more prudent spending,'' Myrick said at one session. ``It is time to stand up, to be counted, to fight.'' The new effort relies heavily on the core strategies of past GOP success: frame the debate on major issues and paint Democrats as the party that taxes as a first resort. Bush pollster Bob Teeter told the gathering that if Republicans articulate their party's differences with Democrats then voters will ``side with the party that taxes last and taxes least, not the party that taxes first and taxes most.'' But Bush's reversal on taxes has many GOP officials wondering whether the president has ditched the Republican Party's defining issue just four months before the 1990 elections. Top party leaders and strategists told GOP officials from across the country that Republicans cannot drop the tax issue, Bush's announcement notwithstanding. And they promised that Bush will protect the party's interests by fighting any attempts to raise income taxes. Matalin believes the message took hold. ``We got done here what we had to do,'' she said in an interview. ``This was the perfect forum for us to remind ourselves that we do best when he define the differences between Republicans and Democrats.'' That such a lesson was necessary appears directly attributable to the absence of Atwater. The energetic, raspy-voiced chairman had become the party's singular spokesman, relied on by the White House and reporters alike. Without him, a party renowned for speaking with one voice suddenly had many, and the message got muddied. ``It has been a little fuzzy and it certainly has been distorted by Democrats,'' Matalin said. ``We've hit a few bumps but we're ready to get back on track,'' said Haley Barbour, a leading GOP strategist and RNC member from Mississippi. Still, even if the GOP can launch a unified offensive, the party's challenge this fall is daunting. The decline of communism has stripped Republicans of one core issue, and Bush's switch on taxes at a minimum makes it tougher for the GOP to get an edge on that front. In addition, the party controlling the White House traditionally loses seats in midterm elections. At the same time, the Democratic Party appears to be having success in articulating a unified message of its own _ a populist pitch blaming Republican greed for the S&L crisis. Not surprisingly, Democratic Party Chairman Ron Brown said the GOP's decision to mount an offensive was made out of fear. ``They don't want to talk about George Bush breaking his `read my lips' pledge and what kind of S&L bailout he is planning,'' Brown said. ``They don't want to talk about America's no-growth economy so, of course, they'll come up with wild charges and finger pointing.'' But Matalin and other GOP leaders left the meeting satisfied that better days lie ahead. ``This is not brain surgery,'' Matalin said. ``This is Campaign 101. We're not going to sit there and let them define the debate.''

DOC.HEAD: Rose Kennedy at 100: In Her Family's Own Words
DOC.TEXT: Eds: Also sent in advance July 10 as b0754.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Rose Kennedy
DOC.TEXT: The celebration of Rose Kennedy's 100th birthday in Hyannis Port is expected to be be the largest Kennedy family gathering in 30 years, since John F. Kennedy was elected president. On the eve of her birthday, these are some of her family's fondest memories:

Edward M. Kennedy, 58, U.S. Senator: ``I was the last one. She was able to spend more time with me. I remember when they came back from London in the middle of the spring and they weren't sure what to do with me. So we went down to the Cape, just Mother and I, and she tutored me herself. ... She's the product of another era. I still tease her about it. Last night she was talking about going to Palm Beach and she was saying, `Isn't it time to start packing the trunks for Florida, Teddy?' I mean, no one says trunks anymore.''

Bobby Shriver, 36, venture capitalist and Special Olympics producer, New York: ``I remember once I was out walking with my grandmother. I was 19. She asked me about my girlfriend I had at the time, if I'd kissed her. I said, yeah, I've kissed her a few times. Then she said my grandfather was the only man she ever kissed. To me, that totally defined her. Like, I kissed one man and he was a hell of a man.''

Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, 39, Maryland Student Service Alliance: ``She loved desserts. When I used to visit she made sure she had four desserts. She'd have pudding and angel food cake and these nice white buttery cookies. She'd say to me, `Do you think four desserts is too much?'''

Timothy Shriver, 30, administrator for at-risk youth, New Haven, Conn. public schools: ``If you asked all the grandchildren if they had a special relationship with her, they'd all secretly think they were her favorite. It was just a quality she had, making you think you were the special one. I had a grammar teacher in D.C. in 10th grade who was really good. I was 16. She was 86. She fired off a letter to this guy congratulating him on my grammar.''

Michael Kennedy, 32, president, Citizens Energy Corp., Boston: ``We used to play a math game. She'd string numbers together and we'd multiply them. The older children could keep up better but she'd focus on one individual and you'd know you were on the hot seat so you better get it right.'

Maria Shriver, 34, correspondent, NBC News, Los Angeles: ``She always ran a very tight ship, like clockwork. She always made sure you were happy with your food. When you were in a group she always sought out your attention, you never got the impression she was too busy. And she always had a regular routine. You always knew at 4:45, there'd be a walk.''

Chris Lawford, 35, actor, Los Angeles: ``I remember the walks. She loved to walk. Back then, it was like the last thing you wanted to do was take a walk with your grandmother, but when I got back, I felt good. It was cathartic. I either learned something, a story about my mother, or I learned something about me.''

DOC.HEAD: Young Read Books, While Their Elders Read Newspapers, Study Shows
DOC.TEXT: Older people are more avid newspaper readers than young people, but the young are more apt to be reading books, according to a study released Sunday. Those who get their news from newspapers appear to be better informed than those who rely on radio, but not necessarily better informed than television news watchers. And people with children are more likely to watch the Sunday morning news interview shows on television than people without. These tidbits are from a new study by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press called ``The American Media: Who Reads, Who Watches, Who Listens, Who Cares.'' The study divides people into four groups based on the interest they show in the news. Twelve percent are news sophisticates who form the regular audience of National Public Radio, public television's ``MacNeil@Lehrer NewsHour'' and such magazines as the Atlantic, Harpers and the New Yorker. Eight percent do not read a daily newspaper or watch or listen to the news regularly. Another 39 percent don't quite make news sophisticate but nevertheless read a news magazine or a major metropolitan daily newspaper or watch Sunday morning interview shows or Cable News Network. They are called serious news consumers. The remaining 41 percent, the largest group, are moderate consumers who regularly read a daily paper or watch or listen to the news. Forty-one percent of the non-news users and 16 percent of the news sophisticates are in the 18-29 age bracket. The analysis was based on 4,890 telephone interviews conducted in the first four months of this year. The margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points. The survey shows that 24 percent in 18-29 bracket said they had read a daily newspaper the previous day. This rose to 61 percent for persons over 80. The percentage increased steadily with age, except for a slight slump among people in their 70s. Forty-three percent of people under 30, one of every two people in their 30s and 40s and 44 percent of people 50 and over said they listened to news on the radio regularly. For television, the percentages were 63 percent under 30, 71 percent in the 30s and 40s and 84 percent at age 50 and over. Five percent of childless people said they watched the Sunday interview programs regularly. This rose to 11 percent for married couples with children and 12 percent for single parents. Thirty-eight percent of people 18 to 29 said they were reading a novel or other book. This increased to 39 percent among people in their 30s and 41 percent for readers in their 40s. After that it dropped off to 35 percent for the 50s and 70s, 31 percent for the 60s and 29 percent for people over 80. The habit of watching CNN regularly rose from 21 percent in the youngest age bracket to 28 percent for people in their 50s and 60s. It dropped to 22 percent for viewers over 70. Among people who had spent one hour or more reading a daily newspaper on the previous day, 20 percent correctly identified Czechoslovakian President Vaclav Havel, compared with 16 percent for those who spent an hour or more watching television news and 11 percent for those who spent that much time listening to news on the radio. In the same survey, 90 percent of the newspaper readers, 92 percent of the television watchers and 82 percent of the radio listeners knew where Panama's Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega took refuge. Forty-seven percent of readers, 50 percent of watchers and 34 percent of listeners knew how the control of the Panama Canal will change.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Says U.S. Knew of Impending Attack
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to ADD there were reports in 1986 that U.S. knew attack was imminent. Pickup pvs 6th graf, `The U.S....
DOC.TEXT: The United States had warning prior to the 1986 bombing of a West Berlin discotheque that Libya planned a terrorist attack, a news magazine reported today. Der Spiegel, West Germany's leading news magazine, said the U.S. government learned that Libya was planning an attack after at least one CIA agent infiltrated the group that prepared the bombing. The blast on April 5, 1986, killed two American soldiers and a Turkish woman and injured more than 200 people in West Berlin's La Belle discotheque, which had been popular with U.S. servicemen. There were also reports shortly after the blast that the U.S. knew an attack was imminent and that planning for the attack was traced to the Libyan Embassy in East Berlin. The U.S. retaliated by bombing the Libyan cities of Benghazi and Tripoli and the heavily guarded compound of Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi. Spiegel's story's appeared to be the first report involving a CIA informer. The flow of information from the informer stopped several days before the La Belle bombing, possibly explaining why the attack on the discotheque was not prevented, the magazine said. The U.S. Embassy in Bonn refused to comment on the magazine's report. The magazine said it based its report on documents from the former East German Ministry for State Security and former East German agents. It also said the documents showed how closely the now-disbanded East German secret police worked with Libyan terrorists. The group that planned the La Belle attack was composed mostly of employees of the Libyan Embassy in East Berlin, the magazine said. Spiegel provided excerpts of its report to news media on Saturday in advance of its Monday publication. Spiegel said the CIA informer apparently was a double agent who also worked for the East German police, or Stasi, and carried the code name ``Alba.'' The agent provided information on the transport of weapons and explosives and on the possible targets of the attack, Spiegel said. The West German newspaper Die Welt reported on Thursday that East Germany's ousted Communist Party leader Erich Honecker and Stasi chief Erich Mielke knew about the planned attack on the disco nearly two weeks before the bombing but did nothing to stop the Libyans.

DOC.HEAD: Kenya Is Latest African Site of Pro-Democracy Turmoil
DOC.TEXT: The winds of democracy blowing from Eastern Europe have reached Kenya, setting off bloody street battles in what had been considered the most stable nation of black Africa. Several political explosions have rocked Africa south of the Sahara this year. Demands for reform have shaken other one-party governments in Ivory Coast, Gabon, Zambia, Cameroon, Zaire and Benin. Analysts say the protests reflect awareness that one-party rule was swept aside in Eastern Europe last year and the weariness of Africans with often authoritarian and corrupt leadership. In Kenya, at least 28 people were killed in riots that began at a banned rally for multiparty politics July 7. The demonstrators stoned a plainclothes policeman and officers responded with tear gas and gunfire, starting four days of street battles that spread to other parts of the country. Multiparty democracy ``is an international catchword which has been adopted by all those who have a grievance against the government,'' said a Western diplomat based in Nairobi. ``They may not know what it means, but they know that they are unhappy and that what they've got hasn't worked,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Rising food prices, skyrocketing debt, burgeoning populations and steady economic decline have added fuel to the political fires. In Zambia, a failed coup July 1 followed five days of the worst urban violence in the nation's history. At least 23 people were killed in student riots over food price increases. The students also demanded Western-style democracy and the ouster of President Kenneth Kaunda, who leads the United National Independence Party, since 1972 the only legal political movement in the southern African country. Protests against austerity measures and corruption in Ivory Coast in March grew into violent anti-government demonstrations demanding that President Felix Houphouet-Boigny relinquish his 30-year monopoly on power. The protests forced him to legalize political organizations other than his own Democratic Party. President Omar Bongo of Gabon installed a multiparty system in May after a coup attempt late last year and student protests in January and February. France sent troops to protect oil workers when more riots broke out in May. Benin also adopted political pluralism after dropping a Marxist-Leninist style of government late last year. Paul Biya, Cameroon's president, came to power in 1983 promising more democracy, but his government has cracked down on advocates of pluralism since February. Six people were killed at a pro-democracy rally and authorities arrested 10 prominent citizens who tried to form an alternative party to his Democratic Rally of the Cameroonian People. Kenya's president, Daniel arap Moi, appears to be following the Cameroonian model. His government has arrested and charged more than 1,400 people in connection with the riots and threatens continued use of force against pro-democracy demonstrators. Seventeen people have been detained without charge, including the most prominent advocates of multiparty politics. Moi, who has governed Kenya since 1978, contends political pluralism would result in tribal-based parties, ethnic divisions and even warfare among Kenya's approximately 40 tribes. A constitutional amendment in 1982 declared the Kenya African National Union the only legal political organization, formalizing a situation that had existed since the last opposition party was banned in 1969. This year, a loose alliance of politicians, lawyers and church leaders began demanding reform on grounds the one-party system had led to corruption, election rigging and increasingly authoritarian rule. Signs of economic distress accompany the pressure for reform. Kenya has experienced steady growth since independence in 1963, but recent gains have been underpinned by heavy foreign aid _ now almost one-third of the budget _ and tourism, sure to be slowed by the turmoil. In recent years, Kenya's 23 million people have been squeezed by double-digit inflation and stagnant incomes. Prices of such basic commodities as flour and sugar have risen under economic restructuring plans of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Economic growth in 1989 was put at 5 percent, but population growth was nearly 4 percent, one of the world's highest rates. Roman Catholic bishops last month lamented a widening gap between rich and poor. Summing up what they called ethical questions of justice and human rights, the bishops said in a pastoral letter: ``What has emerged clearly from the public debate on the political system is a general agreement that the present structures have weaknesses that need to be set right.'' The Organization of African Unity addressed similar issues at its annual meeting last week in Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia. Noting that fundamental changes were occurring in Africa and the world, the member nations pledged in a final communique to ``recommit ourselves to the full democratization of our societies.'' Moi was not present for the declaration. He left the meeting on its first day to return to Kenya, where police battled with those calling for change. He blamed he violence on ``hooligans and drug addicts.''

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Demand Compensation For World War II Victims
DOC.TEXT: About 150 elderly Koreans shouted anti-Japanese slogans Saturday outside the Japanese Embassy in a demonstration demanding compensation for victims of World War II. Riot police and their buses lined the street along the downtown embassy's walls and blocked the protesters from approaching. The protesters, whose family members were drafted by Japan and killed in the war, dispersed peacefully after asking Japan to compensate the war victims. It was their final rally winding up a monthlong march across the nation. The march began in the southern port city of Pusan to draw public attention. Japan drafted tens of thousands of Koreans and forced them to work as laborers or soldiers during World War II. Korea was under Japan's colonial rule for 35 years, beginning in 1910. U.S. and Soviet troops ended the Japanese rule, but the peninsula was divided immediately into Communist North Korea and the capitalist South. The protesters demand full compensation from Japan and an apology from Japanese Emperor Akihito for wrongs committed against Koreans during the war. During a visit by South Korean President Roh Tae-woo in May, Akihito said he felt ``deepest regret'' for the pain Japan's harsh colonial rule had caused the Korean people.

DOC.HEAD: Politburo Stripped of Top Officials in Break with Party Domination
LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday cleared the Communist Party Politburo of the country's most important officials in a final break with a decades-old precept of total party domination. A new Central Committee, elected on the last day of the party's 28th congress, in turn chose a 24-member Politburo packed with the Communist Party leaders of the 15 republics, moderate reformers and political unknowns. Gorbachev and his newly elected deputy, Vladimir Ivashko, were the only holdovers from the previous 12-man Politburo. It was clear the Politburo would not wield the total power it once had. But government ministers remain in place, and they appear now to be the most powerful men in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev holds government power as Soviet president while he continues to lead the party. Even though they are no longer Politburo members, Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov remains in charge of the economy, Dmitri T. Yazov remains defense minister, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov is still KGB chief and Eduard A. Shevardnadze remains foreign minister. The structural changes move their base of power from the Communist Party apparatus to the government, a goal that Gorbachev has espoused for at least two years. He has tried to reshape the party so it concerns itself with broad policy goals rather than the country's day-to-day affairs. Before Gorbachev's reforms began, any high government position was secondary to the official's standing in the Communist Party. Until Saturday, it was understood that combination with a high party position was an indication of a government official's power. ``The new composition of the Politburo underscores that the party fully breaks with the former practice when it was organically built into the command and administrative system, and was on the top of the hierarchy,'' said Ivan Frolov, the editor of the party newspaper Pravda and a new Politburo member. ``It will now be a force competing with other social and political forces and asserting its advantages mostly in the ideological and political struggle,'' he told a news conference. Ryzhkov, Kryuchkov and Yazov remain members of the 412-member Central Committee. Shevardnadze, however, does not. Shevardnadze and Gorbachev adviser Alexander N. Yakovlev, a member of Gorbachev's Presidential Council, said during the congress that they did not see the need to remain on the Politburo. Gorbachev's traditionalist rival, Yegor K. Ligachev, was trounced by Ivashko in his bid for the party's No. 2 job and announced he was going home to Siberia to write a book. The leader of the radical reform wing, Boris N. Yeltsin, quit the party on the day before the congress ended, and some of the country's most prominent reformers quickly joined him. Gorbachev expressed ``contempt'' for those who quit the party, but acknowledged that the Communists were facing the beginning of a multiparty system. He pledged that the party would try to help government bodies rather than simply dominate them. Frolov said that in addition to the heads of party organizations in the Soviet republics, himself, Gorbachev and Ivashko, the new Politburo will include: _Alexander S. Dzasokhov, a former ambassador to Syria and currently chairman of the Supreme Soviet parliament's International Affairs Commission. He will be responsible for party ideology. _Yuri Prokofiev, the Moscow Communist Party chief, a job that in the past has entitled the holder to Politburo status. Prokofiev is known as a moderate reformer. _Galina Semyonova, editor-in-chief of ``Peasant Woman'' magazine. She will be responsible for women's issues. _Gennady Yanayev, who became head of the Central Council of Trade Unions this year after labor unrest began spreading through the country. He will be responsible for international affairs. _Oleg Shenin, the party leader in the vast Krasnoyarsk region of Siberia. His will handle organizational issues. _Igor Stroyev, elevated last year to the party's secretariat by Gorbachev. He will be responsible for farm issues. Boris Gidaspov, the Leningrad party chief whom reformers suspect of being a hard-liner trying to undermine Gorbachev, was elected a national party secretary. It is unclear how the Politburo's function will change, but it appeared unlikely to meet as frequently. Weekly Politburo meetings for years thrashed out decisions on all key policy questions. By putting the party chiefs of the 15 republics on the Politburo, Gorbachev has tried to give the party a better forum for discussing ethnic issues. They range from hard-liners such as Mikolas Burokjavicus, the head of the small Lithuanian party loyal to Moscow, to Georgian Givi Gumbaridze, who is leading his republic's party to endorse the drive for local sovereignty. Their selection ensures that the party's highest body no longer will be dominated by Russians who gradually worked their way through the party apparatus to important jobs in Moscow. Frolov reported a ``very heated'' debate in the Central Committee over which of two candidates from the Baltic republic of Estonia to select. They settled on Enn-Arno Sillari, a representative of the faction that has announced its intention to split from the party.

DOC.HEAD: Stangeland Leads Charge To Fatten Farm Bill For Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: With a tough campaign looming back home, Rep. Arlan Stangeland didn't miss a chance to talk turkey to his constituents in Washington. As the House Agriculture Committee put its final touches on a new five-year farm program, the Republican won approval for a turkey research center down the road from his lake house at Pelican Rapids, Minn. Pork-barrel research projects are nothing new in Congress. But congressional sources say lawmakers rarely use the farm bill to get them adopted. ``It's in the congressman's best interest and the interest of the people of the 7th District to have that facility in our district,'' said Tom Hanson, a spokesman for Stangeland. After the committee's 16-12 vote to authorize $500,000 for planning Stangeland's project, other panel members lined up to fatten the mammoth farm bill with a long menu of special studies or projects. Illinois Rep. Edward Madigan, the committee's ranking Republican, won approval for research at Illinois State University on raising fish. Texas members got authorization for researching prickly pear cactus and mesquite, a prolific Southwest shrub for which the government once had an eradication program. Opponents hope to strip the projects from the farm bill before it goes to President Bush. Critics, who complain that research should be funded on merit rather than politics, say earmarked programs divert scare federal funds from existing projects. ``They just don't have the money to fund centers for all 50 states that people think are important,'' said Chuck Benbrook, executive director of the National Academy of Sciences' board on agriculture. ``You can easily argue that we need more turkey research,'' said Rep. George Brown, D-Calif., who chairs the agriculture committee's research panel. ``But that's a decision that the Department of Agriculture should be making.'' Brown tried in vain to block Stangeland's project, arguing that it shouldn't be approved without a hearing and testimony from USDA experts. He has allies besides USDA. The Senate Agriculture Committee turned down members' pet projects and went on to propose a commission to find wasteful research that Congress should stop. If he succeeds in getting House and Senate negotiators to eliminate the projects, the project sponsors will still enjoy short-term political gain back home, Brown said. If he fails, they will still have to convince the congressional appropriations committees next year to put the projects in the federal budget. The turkey research center would be run by North Dakota State University. The school proposed the facility to Stangeland because scientists want to do genetics research to improve turkey production in northern climates, Hanson said. ``The congressman felt that with Minnesota being second ranked in turkey production in the country and that since 50 percent of the turkeys grown in Minnesota are grown in the 7th District it would be a natural place to have it,'' He said.

DOC.HEAD: There's Still Plenty of Work Ahead
AN AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: While the London and Houston summits are behind him, there are plenty of loose ends that President Bush will have to confront in the next few months. Major differences remain among the allies on trade, the environment and on economic aid to the Soviet Union. Face-saving compromises reached by summit partners to achieve common ground on several issues only guarantee that the divisions will resurface at a later time. At first glance, Bush appears to have gotten most of what he wanted from the NATO summits in London and the summit of industrialized democracies in Houston last week. ``That's what Bush is good at,'' said Stephen Hess, a scholar at the Brookings Institution who specializes in the presidency. ``He's brought to international relations the same skills that he's brought to domestic politics: when you have no money, split the difference.'' He added: ``It's a way to put off decisions without leaving anyone too unhappy.'' But the compromises either glossed over the lingering differences or bought participants more time. For instance, the allied leaders in Houston were able to put off the issue of a joint stance on direct economic aid to the Soviet Union _ favored by West Germany but opposed by the United States _ with a statement that talked about individual aid. It also commissioned a study of the Soviet economy by the International Monetary Fund. A six-month time frame was put on the IMF study. When that report is complete, it is likely that the divisions among Western allies will resurface. Bush also made little real headway on the hotly debated subject of agricultural subsidies. Initially, the administration had pressed for an agreement eliminating all such subsidies by the year 2000. European allies balked at that notion. From the Houston summit came a ``compromise'' in which the United States basically abandoned its insistence that all agricultural subsidies be dropped by 2000; and European allies agreed in principle that the subsidies should be cut. However, that just threw the debate back to negotiations under way in Geneva under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Those talks, to produce a new set of liberalized international trading rules, have been going on for three years _ and are bogged down on the agricultural subsidy issue. Bush has said repeatedly that he hopes the trade talks can be completed _ and an agreement on agricultural subsidies reached _ by the end of this year. But if the year ends and the talks remain deadlocked, Bush will be forced to address the issue anew. On the environment, Bush persuaded allies to retreat from insisting on a timetable on combatting global warming. However, his administration remained at odds with Western allies on the subject _ and with basically the same differences coming out of the summit as going in. At the London NATO summit, allies invited Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address a meeting of the alliance, probably in December. And although the precise forum wasn't specified, U.S. officials said it was unlikely that Gorbachev would address a NATO meeting without Bush in attendance. Furthermore, both Bush and Gorbachev have pledged to try to complete work on treaties by the end of this year _ one to reduce conventional forces in Europe and the other cut long-range nuclear missiles. A third Bush-Gorbachev summit seems likely, possibly in Moscow, to sign a nuclear pact once negotiations on it are complete. And completion of talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe will produce a 35-nation summit among European nations of both Eastern and Western blocs. In the meantime, Bush is turning his attention to domestic issues and fund-raising excursions to help Republican gubernatorial and Senate candidates. ``He'll switch over to non-stop politicking,'' said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen.
