It will take the museum about a year to identify, preserve and catalog what was found during the week in the cave. Some of them will be displayed at the Indianapolis museum in February, Richards said. The diggers believe the dire wolf jawbone found in this year's painstaking work matches another piece of jawbone and a skull found last year. ``You dig and dig until all of a sudden you hit bone, and you start pecking around it little by little so you don't damage it, but you don't know what you have,'' said Chip Bickley. ``Finally when you come through to the bone, it's all worth it,'' said Bickley, who spends the rest of the year working on state historic buildings.

DOC.HEAD: Playwright Criticizes Government Art Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: New government guidelines on art submitted for funding through the National Endowment for the Arts are preposterous and dangerous, Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Edward Albee said Saturday. ``We are turning into a passive society that wishes to be entertained, to be taken out of itself, to be fed easy truths,'' he said. ``Simply because you are putting money into the arts doesn't mean that you have the right to diminish the arts.'' Bills to continue the NEA are pending in both the House and Senate, and a fight is expected over several proposals to apply provisions restricting federal subsidies from going to art that is deemed obscene, sacrilegious or otherwise offensive. Albee, winner of several Pulitzer Prizes and author of ``Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' spoke to about 200 people at Carnegie Mellon University's College of Fine Arts after accepting the Carnegie Mellon Commitment to Playwriting Award. Albee said the atmosphere of the 1960s and the Kennedy administration fostered creative expression. ``The government began pouring millions and hundreds of millions of dollars into the arts through the National Endowment,'' he said. ``Artists were willing to live dangerously and go out on a limb. ``What is happening today is something we should worry about more. Any art that is safe is dead. And any society that will not participate in the danger of the arts is a society in great danger of going down the drain.''

DOC.HEAD: Half of Americans Thinks Probers Unfairly Focusing on Neil Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS overline, 2nd graf to fix spelling to Neil sted Neal Bush
DOC.TEXT: Half of Americans think that federal regulators are unfairly focusing on the involvement of the president's son in the Silverado Savings and Loan case, according to a magazine poll. Newsweek also reports in its July 23 issue that 42 percent of those asked don't think it's unfair for investigators to look into Neil Bush's business dealings. The telephone poll, conducted by The Gallup Organization, indicated that 70 percent of Americans think Neil Bush's involvement is damaging his father, President Bush. Despite that, 72 percent of those surveyed said the president's son should be able to engage in any business, including those that receive federal loan guarantees or deal with the government. A large majority, 81 percent, think that the S&L scandal should be an important issue in the next presidential election, although neither political party was clearly blamed for the scandal, Newsweek said. Republicans were blamed for the scandal by 35 percent and 19 percent blamed the Democrats while 16 percent said both political parties were to blame. Other findings in the poll were: _ 59 percent think the S&L scandal is very serious. _ 72 percent oppose a special income tax surcharge to pay for the S&L bailout. Gallup polled 756 adults between on Thursday and Friday. The margin of error is 4 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Reported in Suburb of Liberian Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The following is a pool report to which Associated Press writer Michael Goldsmith contributed.
DOC.TEXT: Government forces trying to protect this besieged capital battled rebels Saturday with rocket-propelled grenades, witnesses reported. The grenades fired by both sides flattened houses in Paynesville, a suburb eight miles northeast of Monrovia, according to reports from travelers to the area. Rebels began some of Saturday's fighting, but most clashes were started by troops loyal to President Samuel Doe, the witnesses said. He is trying to stall a drive against the capital by the insurgent National Patriotic Front of Liberia. Diplomats said there had been no major gains by either side and the military situation appeared to be static. The rebels encircled the city after beginning their offensive from the far northeast corner of this West African nation six months earlier. Diplomatic sources said there were persistent reports of fighting between rival groups of rebels. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, suggested this might have been one reason for the delay in the assault on Monrovia. Rebel leader Charles Taylor acknowledged a split as long ago as May, saying one of the senior rebel leaders, Prince Johnson, had summarily executed rebel commanders without trial. This besieged Atlantic coast capital, virtually cut off from the outside world by land, sea and air, was again without power and piped water supplies Saturday. A municipal generator that had been shut down for a week restored electrical power from Friday evening to Saturday morning and then shut down again. There was no explanation for the renewed outage, but the generator was powered by diesel fuel, which is in short supply. Several aid groups, including the International Committee of the Red Cross, Doctors Without Borders, and Catholic Relief Services, have begun distributing rice to residents who have been eating roots and leaves because of food shortages. The rice had been stored since June in warehouses where it was deposited by the United Nations. U.N. staff members were pulled out of Liberia after refugees housed in their compound were attacked by some of Doe's troops. U.N. spokesman Francois Giuliani said about eight masked soldiers killed a guard and abducted about 30 people. One of the U.N. warehouses was looted by Doe's soldiers, but a second was opened to the relief agencies. They distributed its contents to the needy while the government provided protection. Checkpoints, created throughout the city as the government defensive position has deteriorated, were more relaxed on Saturday. Soldiers waved some travelers through without inspection. The guerrillas accuse Doe's government of corruption, tribalism and suppressing the opposition. They have said they will lay down their arms only after Doe leaves office. Negotiations in neighboring Sierra Leone have failed to end the conflict. Doe took power in a 1980 coup that ousted elitist descendants of American slaves who founded Liberia in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Cool In Central States, Rain In Southwest And East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0581 to CORRECT coding.
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms that generated at least one tornado were scattered over the eastern half of the nation Saturday, and locally heavy rain caused flooding in the Southwest. Temperatures plunged to record lows from Michigan to Texas. Many showers and thunderstorms had developed by early afternoon from New Jersey, eastern Pennsylvania, Maryland, western Pennsylvania and western New York state southward across Georgia and Florida. A tornado touched down around noon at Preston, Md., and a storm that might have been a tornado caused damage during the morning at New Port Richey, Fla., the National Weather Service said. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.76 inches at Tampa, Fla.; 1.06 inches at Knoxville, Tenn.; and 1.06 inches at Mansfield, Ohio. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered over central Alabama, southern Mississippi, southern Arkansas, northern Illinois, northeastern Iowa, western Lower Michigan and eastern Wisconsin. Rain also was scattered from southern Nevada and western Arizona across New Mexico, southwestern Texas and Colorado into the Nebraska Panhandle. Locally heavy rain during the early morning along the arid lower Colorado River Valley caused street flooding at Bullhead City, Ariz., and near Needles, Calif., the weather service said, and left an inch or two of water standing on roads between Lake Havasu and Parker, Ariz. Heavy rain Friday over the headwaters of the Puerco River in New Mexico caused high water along the river paralleling Interstate 40 in Arizona during the night. Record lows reported were 57 at Abilene, Texas; 51 at Amarillo, Texas; 61 at Beaumont-Port Arthur, Texas; 63 at College Station, Texas; 50 at Concordia, Kan.; 62 at Dallas-Fort Worth; 66 at Del Rio, Texas; 50 at Dodge City, Kan.; 47 at Goodland, Kan.; 62 at Houston; 63 at Lake Charles, La.; 55 at Lubbock, Texas, a tie; 43 at Marquette, Mich., tie; 43 at North Platte, Neb.; 50 at Pueblo, Colo.; 56 at San Angelo, Texas; 64 at Shreveport, La.; 50 at Sioux City, Iowa, tie; 51 at Topeka, Kan., tie; 67 at Victoria, Texas; 60 at Waco, Texas; 52 at Wichita, Kan., tie; and 58 at Wichita Falls, Texas. The record lows at Amarillo, Houston, and Waco tied their records for the whole month of July. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 42 at Kearney and Ord, Neb. Hot air settled in California's southern San Joaquin Valley. Bakersfield had already heated to 101 by 9:30 a.m. On Friday, the heat hit the San Francisco area, with highs of 106 at Morgan Hill and 103 at Livermore, and Pacific Gas & Electric Co. experienced the highest demand for power in northern and central California in the utility's 85-year history. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 57 at Arcata, Calif., to 103 at Bakersfield.

DOC.HEAD: Bear Enthusiasts Just Grin and Eat It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `During the...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that bear meat eaten since 18th century, but every year for three decades; picks up 5th graf pvs, ```Bear eating...'; DELETES last graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A Baptist church founded in the mountain wilderness 215 years ago will celebrate its anniversary Sunday with a ``bear feast'' to honor the animal that helped keep its founders alive. ``It wasn't easy for the settlers to bring cows, sheep and other domestic animals across the Allegheny Mountains,'' said the Rev. Joseph Gluck, pastor emeritus and historian of the Forks-of-Cheat Baptist Church. ``That's why the black bear became one of the great sources of meat for the people who founded our church,'' Gluck said. ``It was a staple. We eat some every year as a sort of memorial. Besides, it's a lot of fun.'' The church, located on a hilltop overlooking the Cheat and Monongahela rivers, has been serving bear meat at its annual picnic off and on since the late 1700s, and each year over the last three decades, Gluck said. The picnics mark the anniversary of the church's founding on Nov. 5, 1775. The celebration is held in July because ``we like to celebrate while the weather is nice,'' said Gluck, 75. ``Bear-eating is not a Johnny-come-lately thing at the Forks,'' said the Rev. Chuck Yoke, the church's pastor. ``The church founders used native bear meat to stay alive in the winter.'' Visitors and others eating bear for the first time are eligible to become members of the World Bear Eaters' Association, said Gluck, who has the title of ``Bear Master'' at the church. ``I say some magic special Indian words, tap them on the head three times with the magic tooth taken from a West Virginia black bear and give them a certificate so they can prove to people they've actually eaten bear,'' Gluck said. ``Mostly, they just grin and eat it,'' said Gluck. The association's membership is approaching 1,500 members, with representatives from at least 24 states and several foreign countries, said Gluck. Hunters from the eastern counties of West Virginia provide the hind quarters cooked for the feast. Gluck said meat from 2-year-old bears is best, because ``Yearlings are too scrawny and meat from older bears is tough.'' Lena Nicholson, 90, has been cooking bear meat for the feast for decades, and she said it's a daylong task. She cuts the bear quarters into roasts, trims the meat and then boils it in water three times. ``That bear meat is awful strong and greasy,'' said Nicholson. ``You have to cook it that much to get down to the good meat.'' The meat is then put into a long pan ``with celery, apple and onion all over it'' and put into the oven for several hours, Nicholson said. ``I have to open all the windows and the door, the smell gets pretty strong, said Nicholson. ``When it comes out, it has a little bit of a beef taste, kind of like a cross between beef and pork. ``People seem to like it real well,'' said Nicholson. ``There's never any left and I've never had anyone complain yet.'' Gluck said he warns those eating bear for the first time that they may notice themselves growling afterward.

DOC.HEAD: DNA Expert: No Semen Links To Defendants
DOC.TEXT: The case against three teen-agers charged with raping a jogger in Central Park has been greatly weakened by the government's failure to link the suspects through DNA samples, a defense lawyer said. An FBI expert testified Friday that semen samples taken from the body and clothes of the victim, an investment banker, did not match up in DNA testing with samples provided by the three defendants. The only sample that was linked to any of 15 people who submitted to the DNA testing came from the jogger's shorts and belonged to her boyfriend, said Special Agent Dwight Adams of the FBI's DNA Analysis Unit in Dallas. The 15 who submitted sambles included the defendants, the boyfriend and potential witnesses at the trial in criminal court. Semen samples taken from the jogger's cervix and her sock matched each other, but did not match the samples of the defendants, Adams testified. Other samples found at the scene were too small to match, he said. ``It weakens the prosecution's case tremendously. It permits us to argue our clients had nothing to do with the rape of the Central Park jogger,'' said Peter Rivera, attorney for defendant Raymond Santana. Prosecutors have said that to get a rape conviction, they don't have to prove the defendants had sex with the jogger, only that they helped other defendants rape her. DNA testing, done through bodily fluids, illuminates a genetic fingerprint unique to each person. When the DNA tests in this case were first made public during pretrial hearings, defense lawyers for the three teen-agers said the results indicated an unidentified person had had sex with the jogger. Prosecutors say the woman was gang-raped and beaten almost to death, then left in a ravine near a popular park jogging route. Santana, 16, Antron McCray, 15, and Yusef Salaam, 16, are on trial for attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in the attack on the woman and two male joggers. The woman, now 30, survived and returned to work, but suffered brain damage and has no memory of the attack. McCray, Santana and Salaam are on trial in an adult court, but if convicted they will be sentenced as juvenile offenders, to up to 10 years in prison. Three other youths are to stand trial on the same charges later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Tackles National Debt
DOC.TEXT: Each year, 76-year-old Gudrun Hertsgaard does what she can to reduce the national debt. This year, she wrote out a check for $300, leaving the balance at roughly $3,000,000,000,000, give or take a few dozen billion. Hertsgaard sent her money to the U.S. Treasury through Citizens for a Debt-Free America, a network of people who chip away at the national debt a few dollars at a time. Just the interest on the debt this year will approach $200 billion, about 15 percent of the federal budget. Friends tell Hertsgaard her annual gestures are futile, but she is undismayed. ``I tend to think small anyway,'' she said. ``I look at the pennies. I try not to think of the millions and billions and trillions.'' Nationwide, 2,345 people contributed more than $4.2 million in the past five years toward retiring the debt, including 29 Minnesotans who gave $26,301. Hertsgaard started sending money to the federal Bureau of the Public Debt in 1986. ``I started with about $50, increasing every year,'' she said. ``I would like to give more. It's more important than anything.'' After her first donation, she received a letter of thanks from the government. ``Your donation and interest in the financial affairs of our country is appreciated,'' states the letter signed by Jo Ann M. Kidwell, section chief, Document Control and Distribution Section, Accounting Control Branch, Bureau of the Public Debt. ``Isn't that just like the government?'' Hertsgaard said. She encourages friends to help reduce the debt, but few do. ``I don't know if it's because they don't give much to charity in the first place or they just don't believe in this. ``But the deficit is so serious,'' she said. ``It puts us at such a disadvantage against other countries. We aren't top drawer anymore.'' She blames the deficits on a national lack of will. ``The defense stuff went way out of balance,'' she said. ``What burns me the most is that they don't ever do much about waste. And then when they do identify something that could be cut, somebody sends up a howl and it doesn't get done.'' Prompted by individual contributions, Congress established the Public Debt Retirement Fund in 1961. Citizens for a Debt-Free America, founded in 1983, is based in New Berlin, Wis.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti's President Orders Arrest Of Returned Exile
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot ordered the arrest of a former paramilitary leader whose return from exile has worried pro-democracy forces. However, the leader remained free Saturday. The provisional president also brushed aside calls for her resignation for her handling of the issue. She indicated she would not step down until elections set for Nov. 4. ``All of us Haitians must unite in order to hold elections that will establish a definite government,'' Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said in an address televised nationwide Friday night. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot is under pressure to arrest two former officials who returned from self-imposed exile last week. The two are believed to be in the capital, Port-au-Prince. Roger Lafontant, who headed the brutal paramilitary police known as the Tonton Macoutes during the deposed Duvalier regime, returned Saturday from the Dominican Republic. Lafontant was also a minister of defense and interior. The other ex-official, William Regala, is a retired major general who was in charge of security during the November 1987 elections. They were aborted after thugs supported by army soldiers killed 34 voters at the polls. He returned from the United States on Tuesday. Their return has given rise to fears it would be impossible to hold free and fair elections and widened a rift between the president and the Council of State. The 19-member Council shares power with the president and has veto power over her decisions. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a former Supreme Court judge, was appointed provisional president in March after military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril fled to the United States amid violent demonstrations. A group of political leaders, including many Council members, has given Mrs. Trouillot's government until Monday noon to arrest the two officers. They have vowed to call for strikes and protests to push for her ouster if the arrests are not made. ``We want her out. We don't trust her,'' said Max Bourjolly, leader of the Communist Party. His party and seven others are pressuring for her ouster. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot also is accused of appointing former Duvalier government officials to the Cabinet without the approval of the Council. On Saturday, the U.S. Embassy said a $10 million loan has been approved for Haiti to buy essential imports, mainly petroleum. President Bush's administration has linked aid, which was cut after the November 1987 election massacre, to free elections this year. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot said she had ordered police to arrest Lafontant, but there was confusion Saturday as to whether the warrant was legal. By late Saturday, there were no reports of his arrest. A new warrant for Regala had not been issued. ``My conclusion is that police don't want to arrest Lafontant,'' said Bayard Vincent, the government prosecutor who issued the new warrant for Lafontant. Two other warrants were issued last week but were not served. Military men have ruled Haiti since Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled in 1986 to exile in France. He took power in 1971 upon the death of his father, Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, who ruled Haiti since 1957.

DOC.HEAD: AP and CWA Reach Tentative Accord
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press and its technical employees reached a tentative agreement Saturday on a new three-year contract, both sides announced. The package is now subject to ratification by the 310 members of the Communications Workers of America. In the agreement the AP dropped its proposal for a deductible on hospital bills. However, the new contract contains a ``managed care'' system for the health plan that the AP had sought. Under the tentative accord, the weekly salaries of top-scale technical workers would increase $23.50 the first year, $24 the second and $24.50 in the third year to $636.50. ``We believe this is a good contract for both sides,'' said Byron Yake, AP's director of Human Resources. ``Adding a third year to the agreement provides everyone with more stability.'' ``The negotiating committee is recommending acceptance of the agreement,'' Ed Cotter, a member of the CWA bargaining committee, said on a telephone hotline set up to inform members about the talks. Last week the union announced that its membership had voted down an earlier two-year contract offer. The new agreement includes increases in pension benefits and geographic differentials in the third year. The new agreement would be retroactive to May 19 and expire May 18, 1993. The technical employees have been working under contract extensions.

DOC.HEAD: Four Injured After Fire on Carrier
DOC.TEXT: A flash fire eight levels below the deck of the USS Saratoga aircraft carrier injured three civilian welders and a sailor Saturday, the Navy said. The men were replacing a pipe at about 2:30 p.m. when the fire started, said Lt. Cmdr. Stephen Hondo, a spokesman for the Naval Air Force at the Atlantic Fleet headquarters in Norfolk, Va. ``One of the injured civilians and the Navy man suffered second-degree flash burns and were flown by helicopter to area hospitals. The other victims were taken by ambulance,'' Hondo said. None of the injuries was life-threatening, he said. Damage to the ship docked at Mayport Naval Station was minimal and the fire burned itself out almost immediately, said Capt. Barry Dysart, executive officer of the Saratoga. ``There was no structural damage to the ship. It will have no impact on our operations at all,'' Dysart said. Both the Navy and Atlantic Marine Inc., the welders' Jacksonville employer, said they would investigate to determine the cause of the fire. The Saratoga is based at Mayport and carries a crew of about 5,000 when fully staffed. It has been undergoing minor repairs since returning in June from training operations along the Eastern seaboard.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Arrives in Moscow for Talks with Gorbachev on German Unification
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details on Kohl visit to Moscow; Tass comments on Woerner visit; comments by West German foreign minister. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany arrived Saturday for talks aimed at soothing the Kremlin's concerns about German unification and winning approval for united German membership in NATO. Earlier in the day, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and NATO chief Manfred Woerner skirted the issue of the military allegiance of a united Germany during talks, but Woerner expressed confidence a solution could be found. Woerner, the Western alliance's highest-ranking official and first NATO chief to visit the Kremlin, said Gorbachev accepted an invitation to address the group at its Brussels headquarters. A date has not been fixed. The official Soviet news agency Tass said that at a meeting between Woerner and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, both sides had agreed that the NATO chief's visit ``was a symbol ... that the Cold War has ended, and Europe is entering a new period.'' Shevardnadze later met Kohl at a Moscow airport, Tass said. Kohl will hold talks with Gorbachev on Sunday in Stavropol, the Soviet leader's home region. West German government spokesman Hans Klein told reporters on Friday that the visit was ``in support of progressing the `two-plus-four' talks on the way to achieving a united Germany in the Western alliance.'' The questions of Germany's military and political obligations are being worked out within the framework of ``two-plus-four'' talks among the two Germanys, the United States, France, Great Britain and the Soviet Union. Woerner's visit to Moscow follows the July 5-6 summit by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in London, where alliance leaders agreed on a new strategy and proposed a non-aggression declaration to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. ``There is a clear coincidence in the approach set out by the alliance in London and the views of the Soviet leadership,'' Woerner said. ``The hand of friendship has been extended on both sides, and there is agreement on building a new relationship.'' Woerner said he told Gorbachev and Shevardnadze that NATO sought cooperation with the Soviet Union and that ``our alliance does not look upon you as an adversary but as a future partner.'' But Woerner, West German defense minister from 1982 until his appointment to the top NATO job in 1988, said the issue of German unity was not discussed. ``Since my Soviet partners didn't raise the issue, I didn't raise it. But I would not draw any conclusion from that at this very moment. The one which I have drawn is that I am confident we will find a solution,'' he said. Woerner said he could understand Soviet fears about a united Germany, given the horrifying experience of World War II. But he added, ``A membership of a united Germany in our alliance would increase stability and would not be a threat of any kind to the Soviet Union.'' Moscow will lose East Germany, a cornerstone of the Warsaw Pact, once the German states merge. It has opposed a united Germany's membership in NATO. Kohl has said he would like the ``two-plus-four'' talks to be wrapped up in time for all-German elections in December. Other hurdles remain, however, including the size of the future German army. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Saturday the Soviet Union would receive a ``binding'' promise on the ceiling for the size of a united German armed forces. Genscher, addressing a meeting of his Free Democratic Party in Zerbst, East Germany, did not specify any figure. The combined armed forces of the two Germanys now number about 600,000, with West Germany alone having 480,000 troops. Genscher made his remarks shortly before he left for Moscow to accompany Kohl. West German officials have said that Kohl will not offer Moscow any more money beyond the already promised $3 billion in government-guaranteed bank loans announced last month to help the Soviet economy shift to a free-market system. At last week's summit in Houston, leaders of the seven major industrial democracies failed to establish a unified approach on the Soviet aid issue. They instead agreed to establish a joint task force which would make non-binding recommendations by the end of the year. West Germany has led the way in offering economic assistance to the Soviets, apparently in an effort to gain Moscow's acceptace of rapid German unification.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says Settlement Urgently Needed To End Apartheid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf `He said ...' with four grafs to UPDATE with Mandela arrival in Mozambique; ADDS scheduled date of return to South Africa. Pickup 6th graf pvs ```Both parties...'
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said Saturday that he and South African President F.W. de Klerk agree a settlement is urgently needed to end white minority rule in their nation. The 71-year-old deputy president of the African National Congress made the comments at a news conference at the end of a three-day visit to Kenya. ``There is an understanding that the longer we delay with a settlement, the more damage will be done to the country,'' Mandela said. Mandela, who arrived Wednesday accompanied by his wife, Winnie, spoke before leaving for Mozambique, the last stop on a six-week of tour of Africa, Europe and North America. Thousands of people welcomed Mandela at the airport in Maputo, the Mozambican capital, where he was greeted by President Joaquim Chissano. Children gave him flower garlands during the welcoming ceremony before the Mandelas left by motorcade for the city center. Mandela is due to return to Johannesburg on Tuesday, one day before his 72nd birthday. At his Nairobi news conference, Mandela said the ANC and government would resume negotiations immediately after his return. The ANC is the leading group fighting white rule. ``Both parties involved are keen on a settlement,'' Mandela said. He said the ANC was prepared to deal with threats by white right-wing groups opposed to the abolition of the apartheid policy of racial discrimination. ``But it is not for us here to discuss what we propose doing about that threat,'' Mandela said. ``But naturally it is a matter that involves priority in our thinking, in our strategy.'' Mandela described ``as genuine, but unfounded'' the fear by some white South Africans that they would be dominated by blacks when majority rule came to the country. ``Our policy makes it clear that we will not tolerate any form of racialism no matter who practices it,'' Mandela said. Mandela refused to discuss the Kenya government's recent attack on supporters of multiparty politics. Six prominent Kenyans have been detained without charge in the crackdown, and at least 28 people were killed in four days of riots that began after police used gunfire and tear gas to break up a pro-democracy rally. Armed riot troops patrolled the city Saturday, apparently bracing for a possible repeat of last week's violence. Mandela also refused comment on an open letter from the wives of seven prominent Kenyan supporters of multiparty politics who either have been detained, are in hiding or have fled the country to avoid arrest. ``We are not keen to be involved in the internal affairs of Kenya,'' Mandela said. ``It is up to the people of Kenya to decide their own affairs.'' The wives had asked Mandela to intervene with Moi on their behalf and secure their husbands' freedom. Mandela looked well after reportedly suffering a slight case of pneumonia and cutting short the Ethiopian leg of his trip Wednesday to seek rest and treatment in Kenya.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Accident Kills 23 People in Mauritania
DOC.TEXT: A bus accident blamed on poor road conditions killed 23 people and injured 29 in this northwest African country, an official report said Saturday. The accident Friday involved a bus carrying about 100 people from the eastern city of Nema to the capital, Nouakchott, the Mauritanian News Agency said. The agency blamed the accident on the poor condition of Mauritania's roads, most of which badly need repair. It did not say whether any other vehicles were involved or provide other details.

DOC.HEAD: Mental Patients March To Protest Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of current and former mental asylum patients from across the nation marched and sang Saturday in a protest against discrimination and inhumane treatment of the mentally ill. ``The consumer rights movement for mental health is the last civil rights movement,'' said Susan Buchsbaum, 31, of Stamford, Conn. ``This movement is about bringing us into the community and giving us a choice about how we want to live and what treatment we want.'' The march marked the end of a five-day convention on psychiatric treatment attended by about 1,000 current and former mental patients and their advocates, whose goals include erasing a perceived stigma associated with psychiatric treatment and advancing a nationwide civil rights movement for mental patients. ``We're declaring that we will not take abuse any longer _ forced drugging, shock treatments that rob you of your power,'' said Caroline Hailer, 25, of Charleston, W.Va. ``We're just as good as anybody else.'' Convention organizers said Saturday was declared National Mental Patients' Rights Day because it fell on Bastille Day, the day the French jail was stormed in 1789 and its inmates _ including a few mental patients _ were freed. Convention delegates, some on leave from hospitals, paraded nearly a mile through downtown chanting, ``Tear down the walls'' and waving signs with slogans like, ``Label Jars, Not People.'' Ms. Buchsbaum, an X-ray technician, said she began fighting for the rights of mental patients after undergoing hospital treatment for depression and a panic disorder as a graduate student. ``I was tied down for three days at a time, injected against my will,'' she said. ``They wouldn't let me talk to my parents.'' Ms. Buchsbaum said she recovered but still battles stereotypes and ``the stigma of having a psychiatric label.'' ``People think we're a bunch of raving maniacs ready to shoot 10 people from the top of a building. That's just not true,'' Ms. Buchsbaum said. ``Most mental patients are outstanding members of society.'' ``We are an oppressed people,'' Gilberto Romero, a Santa Fe, N.m., mental-health advocate told a rally. ``We suffer from discrimination, from prejudice, from disenfranchisement and from stigma.''

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Leader Goes to Egypt to Build Ties
DOC.TEXT: Syrian President Hafez Assad arrived Saturday for his first visit in more than 13 years, making another step in his rapprochement with Egypt. The three-day visit was Assad's fourth summit this year with President Hosni Mubarak. Their two countries resumed diplomatic ties in December. Saturday's visit came amid indications of intensified efforts by Mubarak to patch up Syrian rifts with Iraq and the Palestine Liberation Organization. The two quarrels and Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war are the most burning issues in inter-Arab relations. Syrian troops, originally sent as Arab peacekeepers, now control most of Lebanon. Mubarak and Assad embraced and kissed after the Syrian leader's plane landed at el-Nuzha Airport on the southern outskirts of Alexandria, Egypt's second largest city. Assad and Mubarak conferred for three hours immediately after they drove from the airport to Ras el-Tin Palace, where the Syrian leader is staying. Egyptian Information Minister Safwat el-Sherif told reporters that the two leaders discussed Arab problems and Egyptian-Syrian relations. He gave no details. The two leaders held a second round of talks in the evening. Then Mubarak hosted a state dinner for Assad and his delegation. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, meanwhile, phoned the two presidents from Tripoli to wish them success, the state-run Middle East News Agency said. It gave no further details. Syria severed ties with Egypt in December 1977, weeks after Egypt's then-President Anwar Sadat visited Jerusalem in a peace drive that led to the signing of a treaty with Israel in 1979. Syria was the last of 16 Arab states to restore diplomatic ties with Egypt after more than a decade of ostracism.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Environmentalist Group Holds Rally
DOC.TEXT: About 250 supporters of the logging industry rallied and marched Saturday in opposition to a November ballot initiative that would limit the California timber harvest. The group, called Mothers' Watch, gathered at a local baseball park and marched half a mile to the Northcoast Environmental Center, a meeting place for organizers of the ``Redwood Summer'' _ a series of anti-logging protests. About a hundred counter-demonstrators, many of them members of the Earth First! environmental group, appeared at the rallies, which were peaceful. Mothers' Watch leader Candice Boak said her group was ``sick and tired of distorted and false publicity produced by unqualified obstructionists which makes it seem as if we want to cut down the last old-growth redwood up here.'' Boak's organization includes relatives of loggers, truckers and wood processers, she said. Boak called for a boycott of 70 businesses she said support Earth First! and urged voters to reject Proposition 130, a measure to provide $742 million for the state to acquire and protect old-growth forests and limit logging.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, 10 Hurt in South African Hotel Bombings
DOC.TEXT: Explosions Saturday shook two hotels in the Johannesburg area, killing two people and injuring 10, police said. They were investigating whether the blasts were acts of terrorism. One explosion late Saturday at a hotel in Roodeport, northwest of Johannesburg, killed one person and injured 10, police said. They said witnesses reported seeing someone role an object that looked like a hand grenade into the hotel bar just before the explosion. There were no further details available immediately. Before dawn Saturday, a hotel frequented mostly by whites was bombed in Florida, another Johannesburg suburb. A black waiter was killed. Commercial explosives, which have been associated with right-wing white extremists, were used in that bombing. Damage was minor. No one claimed responsibility for either bombing, but police said they were investigating the attacks as terrorism acts. Right-wing whites issuing statements from hiding have claimed responsibility for a recent spate of bombings aimed at blacks and whites who oppose apartheid. But the explosion at the Will Smith Hotel in Florida did not appear to fit the pattern. Florida is a middle-class and working-class area. Most whites there tend to be relatively conservative. At the time of that blast, there were about 130 patrons at the bar, all of them white, said Rod Rodrigues, one of the hotel owners. In another development, police said there was an explosion Saturday morning at the suburban Johannesburg home of a right-wing white, Hans Binneman. No one was injured, police added. The independent South African Press Association said Binneman was a member of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement. It quoted police as saying he was recently was detained for questioning about earlier bombings in Johannesburg. Police say they suspect right-wing whites in the recent attacks, and nine have been detained for questioning. No one has been charged. Right-wing whites have vowed to resist President F.W. de Klerk's plans to dismantle apartheid and share power with the 30-million black majority. The African National Congress, the leading black opposition group, supports a guerrilla campaign against the government. But it has ended major attacks in the past year.

DOC.HEAD: France Shows Off Military Might on Bastille Day
LaserPhotos PAR1,8,10
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with evening show; pickup graf 9 `A trio...'
DOC.TEXT: France showed off the nation's military strength in a Bastille Day parade Saturday, and President Francois Mitterrand pledged to keep the nation's nuclear force independent and strong. Later in the day, flamboyant showman Jean-Michel Jarre lit up western Paris before more than 2 million people in a spectacular music and light show. Earlier, 7,000 servicemen trooped down the Champs-Elysee to celebrate the start of the French Revolution. In his remarks, Mitterrand told television journalists, ``Defense is part of the imperial obligations of the nation.'' ``I absolutely don't want to reduce it,'' he said, ``even more so because there hasn't been a real reduction in the nuclear potential of the United States or the Soviet Union.'' France refuses to endorse the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's recent change of doctrine making nuclear weapons a ``last resort'' in any conflict with the Warsaw Pact. French officials have said flexibility is a key to nuclear deterrence. ``The international situation has changed, tensions have diminished. The duty of vigilance by the army, however, hasn't diminished,'' Mitterrand said. July 14 marks the fall of the Bastille prison in 1789. The event sparked the French revolution that toppled Louis XVI and gave France its first republican government. The daylong festivities were capped by Jarre's extravaganza. During his show, the year-old Grande Arche and adjacent skyscrapers in the financial district of La Defense were bathed in dazzling, swirling colors. They changed in rhythm to Jarre's symphonic rock music, while searchlights and fireworks formed a canopy overhead. People packed the banks of the Seine on the capital's western edge and a two-mile stretch of avenue to the Arc de Triomphe. The crowd was estimated at 1.5 million before the concert began, but hundreds of thousands more people, from toddlers to nuns, kept filling distant streets as it started. Many were unable to get a direct view, but video screens were set up as well. The Culture Ministry underwrote the show with $8.18 million to allow Jarre to put it on for free. ``I want a celebration for the people _ open and free to everybody,'' said Jarre. The morning parade featured 7,000 soldiers, sailors, firefighters and police officers marching from the Arc de Triomphe to the Place de la Concorde to salute Mitterrand. A trio of aerobatic jets led off the parade, laying down blue, white and red contrails over the route to match the colors of the huge tricolor fluttering under the Arc de Triomphe. About 600 tanks and other armored vehicles lined the avenue or paraded noisily along the three-quarter mile route. The vehicles represent about 15 percent of France's armored forces. The loudest applause was reserved for the bearded companies of Foreign Legionnaires, dressed in desert khakis and their trademark white kepis. The Napoleonic-uniformed Republican Guards, who provide ceremonial security at the presidential palace, also drew cheers as they trotted down the Champs-Elysees on cavalry horses, flashing their gleaming chrome sabers. Also featured were state-of-the-art Mistral ground-to-air missiles, capable of reaching speeds of 1,864 mph to knock down enemy aircraft. A platoon of World War II-era tanks, similar to those that liberated Paris from the Nazi occupation 50 years ago, also were on display. One bore the name De Gaulle, in tribute to wartime leader Gen. Charles de Gaulle. France is celebrating the 100th anniversary of his birth this year.

DOC.HEAD: Scaffolding Erected to Hasten Freeway Opening
With AM-Blue Line
LaserPhotos LA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Workers erected metal scaffolding Saturday to shore up a subway tunnel that partially caved in during a blazing hot fire and was threatening the collapse of a stretch of downtown freeway. The 1{-mile stretch of the Hollywood Freeway was closed for a second day because of fears it would collapse under the vibrations of cars and trucks. A 100-foot section of a Metro Rail Red Line subway tunnel adjacent to the freeway collapsed Friday when fire raced through construction materials inside it. The subway line is part of a 150-mile rail grid planned for Los Angeles. Mayor Tom Bradley on Saturday inaugurated the first stretch of the system, a 22-mile electric commuter train line beteeen downtown Los Angeles and Long Beach. The tunnel blaze broke out shortly before 2 a.m. Friday and portions still smoldered Saturday afternoon. The cause remained unknown, but deputy Fire Chief Ray Rojo said there were no indications of arson. Six workers in a nearby tunnel smelled smoke when the fire broke out and escaped unharmed. Damage was put at $5 million. About 250 feet of the tunnel runs under the freeway, which is part of U.S. Highway 101. The portion under the freeway is surrounded by an 8-foot-thick band of chemically treated concrete or grout; the failed portion was not. Officials said that made all the difference: the cave-in stopped just 10 feet from the freeway. ``The chemical grout prevented a cave-in,'' said Dave Roper, deputy district operations director with the California Department of Transportation. ``The one area that wasn't chemically grouted collapsed. That tells us something.'' Traffic chaos reigned on Friday, and authorities hoped to have the freeway open for the Monday commute. About 250,000 vehicles use the route daily. The contractor did not use grout on the section that collapsed because it was topped by vacant land, Roper said. In the collapsed portions, the blaze ate away wood supports and about 16 feet of earth and metal framing tumbled down. Timbers that were part of the tunnel support system continued to smolder Saturday as firefighters let embers burn themselves out. The tunnel's metal ribs stayed intact but some twisted from the intense heat of the blaze, which hit 1,500 degrees. Despite the fire, the $1.3 billion, 4-mile Metro Rail system, which is 18 months behind schedule, will open as planned in September 1993, said Al Perdon, assistant general manager for Southern California Rapid Transit District. The damaged tunnel is only a spur, not the main tube that will transport passengers in trains, official said. Even if the damaged tunnel isn't fixed in time, a parallel tunnel can be used temporarily in its place, Perdon said.

DOC.HEAD: Zulu Party Lets in Whites to Rival Mandela's Group
DOC.TEXT: The Zulu political organization Inkatha opened its doors to whites Saturday as it pressed its campaign to rival Nelson Mandela's group as a leader in the fight against white rule. The announcement came at the party's congress in the capital of the KwaZulu homeland, Ulundi. Some whites joined the blacks at the event. Mangosuthu Buthelezi, leader of both Inkatha and the Zulu homeland, announced that Inkatha would participate as a multiracial party in elections he hopes will take place before a new constitution is negotiated to end apartheid. President F.W. de Klerk is negotiating to give the country's black majority a say in the political system. Inkatha's chief rival is the African National Congress, whose leaders include Mandela. There are some whites in the ANC leadership, most notably Joe Slovo, the head of the South African Communist Party. Supporters of the ANC and Inkatha have been fighting for power in KwaZulu and Natal province since 1985, leaving more than 4,000 people dead. Both Inkatha and the ANC oppose apartheid but differ over plans for a future South Africa. Inkatha is relatively conservative and contends the ANC is unjustly trying to claim the role of principla negotiator for the black majority. Buthelezi referred to the rivalry with the ANC in his speech to the party congress. ``We will just not allow the ANC and its South African Communist Party partner to crush all opposition to it and emerge as the only viable political party,'' Buthelezi said. ``Nothing that the ANC can do will shake Inkatha's resolve to come out as a new Inkatha and a political party to claim its rightful place at the negotiating table,'' he said. The party congress adopted a platform calling for multiparty democracy, peace and reconciliation, education for all South Africans, equality before the law, respect for cultural heritage, and wealth creation to help the underprivileged. Inkatha was formed in 1975 to organize Zulus against attempts by the South African government to turn the KwaZulu homeland into an independent state. Buthelezi and his organization successfully resisted the policy, which would have stripped Zulus of their South African citizenship. Inkatha became the dominant political party in the Zulu areas and runs the homeland's semi-autonomous government. The organization claims 1.5 million members. Buthelezi has described it in the past as a cultural liberation movement, but it began admitting non-Zulus in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says He'll Agree to Nearly $43 Million In Shipping Suit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 2nd, `An award ...,' and SUBS 9th graf pvs, `Defense attorney ...,' with four grafs to UPDATE with company reaction
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese company will likely face a $43 million penalty for keeping double books to avoid paying union wages to the Filipino crew of a logging ship, a federal judge said. An award that size would be the largest wage judgment in maritime history, said Richard Dodson, a lawyer from Louisiana who represented the 21 crew members in U.S. District Court. A defense lawyer said Saturday the shipping company would appeal the judge's expected decision in favor of the plaintiffs. Delica Shipping company officials said the company kept two sets of books on all 10 of the company's ships for the past eight years. Pine Forest, the company ship involved in the lawsuit, was seized in Tacoma in January and released only after the owner posted a $19 million bond. ``They admitted they cheated,'' Dodson said Friday. Both sides agreed that crew members were required to sign two sets of monthly wage receipts, one indicating payment according to levels specified in agreements with the International Transport Workers Federation and another showing the actual pay rate. Forest Pine crew members said they were paid one-fifth the contractual rate after being hired in March 1989. When 13 of the crew asked to leave the ship to pursue wage claims, they were blacklisted from future work, testimony indicated. Company lawyers argued unsuccessfully that Judge Jack Tanner lacked jurisdiction because no cargo was unloaded in western Washington state. Under U.S. law, the courts have jurisdiction over wage cases involving foreign ships and crews when their voyages end in U.S. waters. Defense attorney Joseph Stacey said Saturday that Delica would appeal Tanner's expected decision against the company. Stacey said the crewmen were paid about 70 percent of union scale wages, not the 20 percent alleged. He said the case covered about 15 different pay grades and that he could not state actual wage amounts. Stacey earlier said the crew members knowingly and voluntarily agreed to less pay than required under the union agreement and that what they did receive was still a highly desirable rate for the Philippines. ``The flag-of-convenience vessels have never paid these ITF wages,'' he said. ``In our case, even the ITF never expected anybody to receive ITF wages.'' In a hearing Friday, Dodson asked Tanner to award $150,000 in back pay, $16 million in compensatory and penalty wages and $27 million in punitive damages from Delica. ``I might as well tell you, you're looking at a judgment near or around that figure,'' Tanner told company lawyers. ``This case cries out for punitive damages in a substantial amount of money, both to punish your client and to deter others from such outrageous, malicious and intentional conduct.'' The judge's decision was expected later this summer. The Pine Forest is registered to Delica, a Panamanian corporation. It flies the flag of Vanuatu, a small Pacific island nation, and is operated by Inui Steamship Co. of Japan, a subsidiary of Mitsui Inc. The ship is chartered by yet another Japanese company to bring logs from the Weyerhaeuser Co. through Tacoma and Longview. Dodson said the double bookkeeping system boosted profits by $400,000 a year. He said he had filed a $100 million civil suit against Delica on behalf of 2,000 other crew members. Another Delica ship, the Fir Grove, also is the subject of a civil case after being seized in Coos Bay, Ore. The Pine Forest case was hailed Friday by Paul Chapman, director of the Center for Seafarers' Rights at the Seamen's Church Institute in New York. ``This case represents a systemic problem that is rampant throughout the shipping industry around the world,'' Chapman said. ``Each year thousands of seafarers are cheated out of their earned wages and are virtually blackmailed into signing false wage receipts and unfair contracts.''

DOC.HEAD: Connie Chung Miffed by Tout Shows
DOC.TEXT: Connie Chung got a little miffed Saturday while being barraged with questions about the glitz factor of her newly redone interview show on CBS. ``You people are so insulting,'' she told a roomful of television critics at the Century Plaza hotel. The reporters were grilling her about the news value of ``Face to Face with Connie Chung,'' formerly ``Saturday Night with Connie Chung,'' which moves with its new name to Mondays at 10 p.m. on July 23. Chung, who also anchors the Sunday CBS evening news, insisted that celebrity interviews were not the driving force of her hourlong program, despite recent network promotions that accentuate her starside chats. The television critics insisted otherwise. ``Look, it's a magazine program,'' Chung said, her voice rising. ``We're going to have all kinds of stories.'' Chung's press conference was part of the annual CBS summer media tour for TV critics. Chung's infamous interview last winter with an uncooperative Marlon Brando was ``an excruciating experience for me,'' she said. ``He toyed with me. He played with me. I think he wanted to direct me.'' The move from Saturday nights to Mondays allows Chung to follow ``Murphy Brown'' and ``Designing Women,'' two of the top-rated programs on CBS. Chung said she hoped the switch would boost her ratings, which never pushed into the high numbers on Saturday, an unpopular night for most television networks. Chung also said she has never been approached to co-anchor the weekly evening news with Dan Rather, despite persistent rumors the network is considering such a move to revive Rather's sagging Nielsen figures.

DOC.HEAD: Government Denies Forcing War Refugees to Return Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs for MINOR EDITING, pickup graf 3 `In its....' INSERTS one graf after 18th `The rebel...' to ADD details on latest fighting; pickup 19th graf pvs `Western relief...'
DOC.TEXT: The government Saturday said it was helping about 190,000 refugees return to the south, where they had fled famine and civil war. However, it denied a U.S. newspaper report that the refugees were being forced to return to their villages in southwestern Bahr el-Ghazal province. In its report Friday, the New York Times quoted village chiefs and U.N. relief workers who said the government was making the refugees go home and further straining food supplies in the region. The article quoted a report by the U.N. Children's Fund, which said the refugees were taken by train and truck for part of the route. It said they then had to walk as many as four days to their villages. Brig. Gen. Pio Yukwan Deng, a member of the ruling military council, dismissed the Times report as ``sheer, unfounded allegations.'' During the 7-year-old civil war in the south, about 2 million refugees have fled the fighting and famine, settling in shantytowns around the capital, Khartoum. Hundreds of thousands of refugees have fled to other Sudanese cities as well as to neighboring Ethiopia and Uganda. Peter Orat, the minister for relief and displaced persons, denied that any southerners were being coerced into leaving the capital. ``Our declared policy is to help the displaced return to the south, not by force but by their own free will,'' Orat said. He said those who wished to remain in the north would not be allowed to stay in their shantytowns but would be moved to nearby ``production areas to help boost production.'' He did not elaborate, but apparently was referring to agricultural areas. The refugees live in about 27 shantytowns around the capital and in the nearby central region. About 10,000 inhabitants of one camp in a suburban industrial area near Khartoum have already been moved to another suburb because the camp's water was polluted. Mohamed el-Hassan Awad el-Karim, the commissioner for displaced people, said that about 190,000 refugees had asked to return to their homes in Bahr el-Ghazal. ``We are currently contacting concerned bodies, local and international, to help us in transporting them,'' el-Karim said. He said it was not possible for the government to transport all the refugees. ``We are providing food for three months in addition to tents, blankets, drugs and agricultural tools to anyone wishing to return home.'' The arrival of large numbers of war refugees in Khartoum and other Sudanese cities has created tensions with local residents who resent having to share their already meager food resources and job opportunities. There are also tribal and religious differences. The southerners are mostly Christians or animists of African origin. The northerners are predominantly Moslem of Arab descent. The rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army took up arms against the government in 1983, demanding more autonomy and a greater share in the country's economic wealth. Government troops killed 160 rebels in fighting this week around the towns of Yei and Maridi in the southern Equatoria region, Brig. Gen. Dominique Kassiano, a member of the ruling military council, said Saturday. He did not mention government casualties. Western relief agencies say that in 1988 alone, more than 500,000 southerners were killed in the fighting or starved to death. For the past two years, the government had prevented the southern refugees from returning home, fearing that they would provide new recruits for the rebel army, the Times reported. The Times article said some relief workers believed that by sending the refugees back, the military government was trying to strain food supplies and disrupt life in rebel-held areas in the south. The military government is led by Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir, who took power in a June 30, 1989 coup that overthrew the civilian Prime Minister Sadek Mahdi.

DOC.HEAD: First Electric Rail Transit in 30 Years Inaugurated in Los Angeles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with subway tunnel shored up after fire, picks up 6th graf, `The old ...; SUBS 15th graf pvs, `As the...' to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: It's back to the future for smoggy, traffic-choked Los Angeles, where electric trolleys rolled again Saturday for the first time in 30 years. ``Thirty years after the last Red Car served this community, today we launch the beginning of the new Blue Line,'' declared Mayor Tom Bradley in a ceremony at the light-rail mass transit line's downtown Pico Station. The 22-mile, $877 million Metro Blue Line runs along an old Pacific Electric Red Car route from downtown to Long Beach. It is the first operating segment of a 150-mile, $10 billion rail grid planned for completion in the next century. President Bush sent a message saying the construction ``demonstrated civic co-operation ... and the kind of local commitment necessary.'' Less than a mile away from the inauguration site, workers erected metal scaffolding to shore up a subway tunnel that partially caved in during a fire that began Friday and was threatening the collapse of a stretch of the busy Hollywood Freeway. The tunnel is part of the 4-mile Metro Rail subway system, a section of the rail grid scheduled to open in 1993. The Blue Line, completed in five years, is an overhead-powered trolley system financed by a half-cent county sales tax voters approved in 1980. The old Red Car system was built 90 years ago and dismantled in 1961 in favor of cars, buses and freeways. That decision also produced some of the worst air pollution in the nation and chronic traffic congestion. ``When 12,000 passengers (per day) ride this Blue Line next year, it will reduce smog problems,'' said Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy. Cheers went up as the politicians clanged a silver bell and one of the red, white and blue $1 million trolleys rounded a bend sounding its horn. ``I was 8 years old when the Red Car stopped running,'' said Corey Smith, a security guard waiting to take a trolley to work at the Long Beach Transit Plaza. ``I have good memories. My grandfather worked as a motorman.'' Smith, who collects Red Car memorabilia, believes the Blue Line will be a success. ``I'm going to take it on a regular basis,'' he said. ``It will take a while for some people to get used to it, but once used to it they will probably leave their cars.'' After the civic leaders and reporters headed south down the line for ceremonies at some of the other 21 stations, the Blue Line began offering free rides for the weekend. A $1.10 fare goes into effect Monday. Eric Jacobson, 35, waited in the 90-degree heat to be among the first to ride. His father had taken him on the last Red Line commute in 1961. ``It was the end of meaningful mass transit,'' he said. ``Now we've come to our senses a little bit. Hopefully this is the start of a viable mass transit system in the L.A. area.'' As the Blue Line began operating, the Hollywood Freeway remained closed for a second day near downtown because of the tunnel fire. The morning rush-hour traffic jam Friday illustrated the freeway system's vulnerability to a single incident and the lack of mass transit alternatives. A dozen Guardian Angels, the self-styled community crime fighters, stood by in their red berets for the Blue Line's debut. A familiar sight on transit lines in the East, they came from San Francisco and San Jose to ride the Los Angeles trolleys. ``The general game plan is to ride from 5 p.m. until it shuts down. That's when most crimes are committed. We'll be a visual deterrent,'' said Trey Scharlin, who is organizing Angels for the Blue Line, which will run until 8 p.m. Concerns have been voiced about the safety of the line, which travels through territory that is home to an estimated 15,000 gang members. The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department has been contracted to provide 118 deputies as security for the Blue Line and its riders.

DOC.HEAD: Protests Small, Hunting Success Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `More than ...,' with two grafs to UPDATE with more than 1,100 prairie dogs killed by end of first day; picks up 6th graf pvs, `Prairie dogs ...' ^Laserphotos NATX1,2
DOC.TEXT: The first Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot competition got under way Saturday with more than 100 shooters, despite the efforts of about two dozen animal rights activists. Two protesters were issued citations for trespassing, authorities said. When plans for the shooting contest became known three months ago, outraged animal rights activists successfully lobbied Gov. Roy Romer and U.S. Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell to come out against it. But local citizens rallied round the organizers, and all but three of 318 people who attended a town meeting on the subject voted in favor of the contest. One of the people at the meeting suggested a ``yuppie shoot'' might be in order, and after the vote, Mayor John Vanderpool invited Romer and Campbell to ``buzz off.'' More than $7,000 in prizes was at stake for hunters in the two-day competition, billed as a way of reducing the population of the foot-tall, grayish brown rodents, relatives of the squirrel. By the end of the hunt's first day, organizers said 1,162 prairie dogs had been killed, way over the maximum 500 predicted. Hunt organizer Roger Culver attributed the high rate to availability of dogs, good weather and marksmen's skill, but added that no shooter had hit the 50 dogs allowed. Prairie dogs have multiplied geometrically in recent years because of the drought, landowner Paul Carkhuff said. ``There used to be oats in that field that'd reach three feet,'' he said. ``Nobody can grow anything on land that the prairie dogs have gotten to like this.'' Six-inch-tall mounds around prairie dog burrows, spaced only a few feet apart, harming plants and creating a hazard for livestock. Animal rights activists, however, believe shooting the animals at all, much less for sport, is immoral. ``It's a contest of cruelty,'' said Shari Janger of Denver, a member of the Rocky Mountain Humane Society and Prairie Dog Rescue. ``We just want them to stop this. They think it's their world down here. It isn't. It's the state of Colorado.'' About 25 protesters appeared at the 6 a.m. pancake breakfast at the Moose Lodge, waving signs and shouting slogans. There were no confrontations or incidents, other than a lot of yelling between the protesters and local residents who turned out to watch the demonstration. Police worked to keep hotheads on both sides apart, said Montrose County Sheriff Tom Gilmore. Many of the locals said they enjoyed the news media activity as much as the demonstrations, and took as many photographs of reporters and television crews as they did of the protesters. ``We've just never had anything like this kind of attention before,'' said Linda Norton, a local merchant and president of the area's Chamber of Commerce, who estimated the combined population of Nucla and nearby Naturita in southwestern Colorado at 1,500. Nucla merchants also were pleased. The only two motels in the region were booked solid for the first time in several years, restaurants and bars were full and souvenior hawkers reported brisk sales. One activist who allegedly crossed onto private property was issued a citation on the spot and a second demonstrator was removed by deputies, taken to the local sheriff's office, issued a summons and released, Undersheriff Mike Wiggins said. ``We gave him the summons, took him back out on the street and turned him around five times and let him go,'' Wiggins said. The hunters, carrying everything from big-game rifles to expensive target guns, were sent out in two-man teams to separate ranches for six hours of shooting. Instead of letting the hunters just blaze away and counting up the carcasses later, organizers established a point system. Successful shots longer than 200 yards counted for two points, those under that distance one point. Hunters were penalized one point for every miss at more than 200 yards and two points at less than 200 yards. Two teams sent to one ranch said they got off 18 shots in the first hour, 14 of them hits. One man complained he and his partner went three hours without taking a shot. Gilmore, who combined forces with neighboring San Miguel County and state and federal land agencies to gather 25 officers, said he would send a bill for the extra law enforcement to the shoot sponsor, the Ten Ring Gun Club. ``We know it won't get paid, but they'll know how much this cost,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Convention Ends With Change of Heart
DOC.TEXT: Delegates to the world conference of the Seventh-day Adventist Church ended their meeting Saturday after making an exception to a hotly debated decision barring the ordination of women. The ruling body of the church voted Wednesday against allowing the ordination of women, after hours of discussion and splits along geographical lines among the 1,500 delegates to the 55th world conference. On Friday, delegates extended to women members some ministerial duties denied in the earlier vote. The change allows local congregations to grant women the right to perform marriages, a duty formerly reserved for ordained ministers. Church spokesman Herbert Ford said the rule change ``does, in effect, allow women to be a little closer to ordination.'' In the earlier decision, delegates had voted along geographical lines, 1,173 to 377, to accept a commission's report that ordaining women would be disruptive to the world church and should not be allowed. European and North American delegates offered the greatest support for ordination, while leaders from Africa, Asia and South American overwhelmingly opposed letting women preach the gospel. The Seventh-day Adventist Church is separated into 11 geographical divisions encompassing 190 countries and 6.2 million members. Robert S. Folkenberg, the church's world leader, capped the 10-day conference in downtown Indianapolis on Saturday, with an overture for tolerance. ``This unity is not uniformity,'' Folkenberg said in addressing the conference during worship service. ``If God wanted a church of uniformity, he would not have made flowers of different colors... ``We are not a family of God unless we are building bridges to all people of all nations.'' Ford said women designated ``local elders'' by their congregation will be allowed to perform marriages with the approval of regional church officials. To become local elders, women must have an undergraduate theology degree and an Adventist seminary graduate degree and gain the approval of their congregation's leaders. The earlier vote was influenced by a report from the church's Role of Women Commission. The report said church unity would be threatened if women were allowed to preach.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill 35 Civilians, Politician Says Army Massacred 1,000
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to ADD comments on war by top army commander. Pickup 4th graf pvs `Defense ministry...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebels stopped three buses and gunned down at least 35 Moslem passengers in eastern Sri Lanka, Defense Ministry officials said Saturday. Also Saturday, a Tamil politician claimed Sri Lankan soldiers massacred nearly 1,000 Tamil civilians during the past month of fighting with the rebels. At least 2,400 combatants and an undetermined number of civilians have died since ethnic Tamils, who are mainly Hindu, violated a cease-fire in June. They renewed their fighting against government troops, who are mostly Buddhist Sinhalese. A top Sri Lankan army commander said Saturday that the military could not win the civil war against the Tamil separatists. ``A political solution is the only way out,'' said Major General G.H. de Silva, who commands the government forces in the eastern region of this island nation. He said the rebels are starting hit-and-run operations, effectively using crude but powerful land mines and guerrilla strikes against the army. ``It is becoming difficult to control territory,'' said De Silva, interviewed with several of his officers in the town of Trincomalee. ``When you hit, he hides. When you move out, he comes back,'' he said, referring to the rebels. Defense Ministry officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the rebels stopped three buses near the eastern town of Kalmunai on Friday and shot and killed at least 35 passengers. All the victims were Moslems, they said. Moslem politicians put the number of dead at 150. Moslems, who make up about 7 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, are often caught in the middle of the 7-year-old war between Tamil rebels and the Sinhalese-dominated government. According to residents of Kalmunai, Friday's killings were intended as a warning to Moslems not to help soldiers hunt for rebel hideouts. In another development, a Tamil politician accused the army of intentionally killing at least 1,000 civilians in the latest bout of fighting, which started last month after the rebels repudiated the 13-month-long cease-fire. ``Since the fighting began on June 11, we fear nearly 1,000 Tamil civilians, men, women and children have been deliberately massacred by the army in the east,'' said Kandian Premachandran. ``We concede civilians die when caught in the cross fire. But what is happening in the east is they are being deliberately massacred,'' he said. There was no immediate government reaction to Premachandran's allegations. On Thursday, Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunge denied news reports that soldiers were killing Tamil civilians after clearing towns and villages of rebels. Premachandran is an opposition member of Parliament and a leader of the Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front, a former guerrilla group that gave up arms before entering politics. The party opposes the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the rebel group militia fighting for an independent Tamil homeland. Tamils make up 18 percent of the population. They claim they are discriminated against by Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population and control the government and armed forces. Tamil militants launched their movement for an independent homeland in 1983. At least 13,400 people have died in the insurrection.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Killed Three Boys Given Death Penalty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with additional quotes, details; SUBS last graf to CORRECT to 10th person on death row sted 9th; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Saturday sentenced to death a man who confessed to torturing and fatally strangling one boy and stabbing to death two young brothers he found riding their bikes in a park. A Clark County Superior Court jury deliberated for three days before announcing the sentence against Westley Allan Dodd, 29, of Vancouver. Dodd pleaded guilty June 11 to three counts of aggravated first-degree murder for the murders of Cole Neer, 11, and William Neer, 10, both of Vancouver, and Lee Iseli, 4, of Portland, Ore. The brothers were stabbed to death on Labor Day in Vancouver's David Douglas Park, where they had gone to ride their bikes. Dodd said he abducted Iseli from a school playground in Portland on Oct. 29 and took him across the Columbia River to Dodd's Vancouver apartment. He repeatedly molested and tortured the boy and finally killed him the next morning. Then Dodd hung the body in a closet for a time before dumping it in a lake. Dodd was arrested about two weeks later when he tried to kidnap a 6-year-old boy from a bathroom at a movie theater in Camas, Wash. The prosecution case included excerpts from Dodd's diary in which he described in pornographic detail how he hoped to sexually torture and kill children. Dodd's scrapbook included photographs he took of Lee Iseli before and after his death. Beneath the photos were graphic and detailed captions. ``He fantasized on it,'' said prosecutor Art Curtis. ``He killed children for sexual pleasure. For fun. For the thrill of the hunt.'' Defense attorney Lee Dane had argued Dodd might be insane. After the sentence, Dane said he was not surprised. ``They evaluated very seriously,'' he said. ``You can't ask for more than that.'' Dodd had been convicted in 1984 of molestation charges in Idaho, and again in 1987 in the Seattle area. Both charges involved young boys. Dodd served 118 days in jail on the Seattle charges. ``It's real scary. He had a normal childhood ... He blossomed into a mass murderer,'' said prosecutor Roger Bennett. Bob Iseli, father of Lee Iseli, said he was happy with Saturday's verdict and didn't feel sorry for Dodd. ``I personally don't feel good about the death penalty,'' Iseli said. ``But if we're going to shed a tear for anybody we're going to shed a tear for my boy and the Neer boys.'' ``Finally they got that piece of garbage off the street,'' said Clair Neer, the father of the brothers. The defense called no witnesses and presented no evidence during the trial, nor did his attorneys engage in any real cross-examination of the state's witnesses. Dodd became the 10th person on Washington's death row under a 1981 state law that sanctions execution by hanging or lethal injection _ depending on the wishes of the inmate. All nine of the previous sentences are being appealed. Dodd's sentence also will be automatically appealed.

DOC.HEAD: Morrison Endorsed, Cibes Promises Primary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Saturday's balloting ...,' to CLARIFY that hasn't been Democratic gubernatorial primary since 1978; ADDS two grafs with other race results, other primaries possible; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut Democrats endorsed U.S. Rep. Bruce A. Morrison for governor Saturday, but gave enough backing to underdog William J. Cibes Jr. to allow a Sept. 11 primary to decide the nomination. Saturday's balloting by 1,449 delegates to the Democratic state convention gave Morrison 69 percent to Cibes' 31 percent. A candidate needed 20 percent to force the holding of a primary. There has not been a Democratic gubernatorial primary since 1978. ``We want a candidate who is on the side of the working- and middle-class families in the state,'' said Morrison, a four-term congressman. ``That is the Democratic Party's legacy, that is what people have been worried about and that's what I have to offer.'' Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill decided in March not to seek a third full term after 10 years in office. Challenged by Morrison for the nomination, O'Neill said he feared a nasty campaign and decided to pull out. He remained publicly neutral, but some of his loyalists worked for Cibes. The primary winner will face Independent Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a former three-term Republican U.S. senator who has a commanding lead in the polls, and Republican John G. Rowland, a three-term congressman expected to be nominated at next weekend's GOP State Conventin. For the first time in decades, the Democrats are not favored to win the governor's race. U.S. Rep. Barbara B. Kennelly called Cibes' decision to force a primary ``a foolish move'' when the Democrats face an uphill battle in November. ``We will go on in September and in November to address the specific fears of Connecticut voters and to be a problem solver to build our future,'' said Cibes, a six-term state representative who has focused on the need for a state personal income tax and reductions in other taxes. Morrison promised to wage a positive campaign against Cibes. The convention also endorsed Morrison's choice for lieutenant governor, former South Windsor Mayor Sandra Bender, who was nominated by acclamation. Like O'Neill, Lt. Gov. Joseph J. Fauliso is retiring. Secretary of the State Julia H. Tashjian and Treasurer Francisco L. Borges also were nominated, by acclamation, for re-election. Meanwhile, state Sen. Richard Blumenthal won the attorney general endorsement, but state Rep. Jay B. Levin qualified for a primary. And former state Sen. William E. Curry Jr. handily won the comptroller endorsement, but four-term incumbent J. Edward Caldwell also qualified for a primary. Levin and Caldwell said they had not decided whether or not to conceed.

DOC.HEAD: Report: White House Will Appoint Outside Experts to Review NASA Problems
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 4th graf prev, now beginning ``I don't xxx to update with WHITE HOUSE no comment; CORRECTS CBC to CBS in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: The White House is getting ready to appoint a panel of experts to review NASA operations in the wake of embarrassing problems with two leaky shuttles and a flawed space telescope, according to a report. CBS-TV reported on its ``Weekend News'' Saturday that the panel probably will be named next week. ``I think the White House is disappointed with the priorities coming out of the agency,'' George Washington University professor John M. Logsdon told the network. ``I think there is a crisis of confidence in NASA as an organization, in its management and its leadership.'' ``I don't have any comments on the CBS report,'' said White House spokesman Sean Walsh. Although the space agency has named committees of its own to look into recent problems, a White House oversight panel could be seen as a response to congressional calls for an outside review of NASA procedures. For example, Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., head of the Senate Commerce space subcommittee, has said that the ``new (NASA) management team, ironically, has been looking at this but the agency hasn't gotten attention from the president and that's what's needed now.'' A White House review of NASA probably would be coordinated by the National Space Council, which is headed by Vice President Dan Quayle and meets next week. CBS said Quayle ``reportedly got an earful of complaints against NASA last week and is expected to take the lead in strategy meetings beginning Monday.'' The network said the White House concern is not so much with NASA's recent string of technical problems, but the agency bureaucracy's failure to deal with them adequately.
