Despite the concern, the report said NASA Administrator Richard Truly, recently appointed by President Bush, still has the White House's confidence.

DOC.HEAD: Western Governors Hold Annual Meeting In Fargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `North Dakota ...' to give first reference for Western Governors Association
DOC.TEXT: American governors meet with their Canadian counterparts this week to strengthen their ties during this period of uncertainty in Canada. Governors from 12 western states, along with the governor of American Samoa, begin their three-day conference on Sunday. The highlight will be a meeting Monday of Premiers Gary Filmon of Manitoba and Grant Devine of Saskatchewan. Representatives from Alberta also will attend. Premier Bill Vander Zalm of British Columbia was invited but said he was too busy to attend. North Dakota Gov. George Sinner, this year's chairman of the Western Governors' Association, said the western United States has much in common with western Canada, and together they can make the West strong. ``We need them, and they need us. We need each other,'' Sinner said. The failure of the Meech Lake accord to win legislative approval last month has left Canadians in confusion and political limbo, Sinner said. The accord, a package of constitutional amendments, would have conferred a special constitutional status on Quebec. Canadians are concerned that its failure might spur a Quebec push for independence. ``There werelots of forces at work to tie the western states to the western provinces, but all those forces have been sharpened now with the uncertainty that prevails in Canada,'' Sinner said. South Dakota Gov. George Mickelson, who will succeed Sinner as WGA chairman next year, said he hoped discussion of such cross-border issues as trade, tourism, the environment and energy would lead to stronger ties between the countries. ``We do a lot of work (with Canadians) already,'' Sinner said. ``We have border commissions to resolve problems. We have the free trade agreement, which God knows has its imperfections. Hopefully, we can build on that.'' The WGA has proposed an office in Canada. A report to be presented at this week's conference recommends locating the office in Ottawa, the Canadian capital. Sinner, who favors locating the office in western Canada, said he was uncertain whether the governors would decide on the location this week. One conference session will feature a discussion involving the governors and five authors and thinkers on the western region. The authors have prepared a book of essays for the group called ``Beyond the Mythic West.'' ``This book is meant to give the flavor of the evolving West, a taste of its visions and thinking,'' Sinner said. The governors also will discuss new policy directions in water and drought management, waste disposal, state and regional efforts to develop international trade and relations with Indians. Govs. George Deukmejian of California, Rose Mofford of Arizona, Kay Orr of Nebraska, Mike Hayden of Kansas and John Waihee of Hawaii are unable to attend the conference. In addition to Sinner and Mickelson, governors expected to attend are Roy Romer of Colorado, Cecil Andrus of Idaho, Rudy Perpich of Minnesota, Stan Stephens of Montana, Bob Miller of Nevada, Garrey Carruthers of New Mexico, Neil Goldschmidt of Oregon, Norman Bangerter of Utah, Booth Gardner of Washington, Michael Sullivan of Wyoming and Peter Colman of American Samoa.

DOC.HEAD: Spiritual Leader of Orthodox Christians Urges Unity
DOC.TEXT: The spiritual leader of 250 million Orthodox Christians said Saturday the third millennium of Christianity should be a time for healing the ruptures that marked church history in the last thousand years. ``Divisions and schisms cannot be justified in the life of the churches,'' Patriarch Dimitrios declared during a special service sponsored by the National Council of Churches at Columbia University. Dimitrios, the first Orthodox patriarch to visit the United States, arrived here from Washington Friday on the second leg of a month-long tour. Saturday evening, Gov. Mario Cuomo hosted a dinner honoring Dimitrios at the Windows on the World restaurant atop the World Trade Center. At the morning service, Dimitrios was welcomed by the Very Rev. Leonid Kishkovsky, an Orthodox archpriest and current president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U.S.A. Kishkovsky said the variety of religion in the United States ``almost exceeds the imagination'' and that many American Christians were ``seeking an overarching and basic Christian identity and unity that ... may be found in the early Christian tradition.'' Dimitrios responded that this century has seen the rise of an ecumenical spirit in the world's religious communities. But the patriarch, whose own church came into being as a result of a great schism with Rome in 1054, said that ``unhappily, the second Christian millennium became a period of successive divisions. ``The ardent wish of all of us is that the impending third millennium will be a time of healing from those wounds,'' he said, speaking in Greek through a translator. ``The return to the undivided church of the first thousand years is not so difficult so long as it is based on common historical and theological sources and is purged of historical prejudices.'' Two hundred people attended the service at the Chapel of Interfaith Center, including Cardinal John J. O'Connor, Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, who welcomed Dimitrios as ``a man who can bridge the gap between East and West.'' Most of the Eastern church's 250 million adherents live in Eastern Europe, but there are 6 million in the United States, including 1 million in the New York area, according to the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese. The 75-year-old religious leader was in Washington for a week to attend the 30th Greek Orthodox Biennial Clergy-Laity Congress. He also will visit Pennsylvania, San Francisco, Chicago, Buffalo and Boston. Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I, installed in 1972, holds the title Archbishop of Constantinople. Based in that city, now Istanbul, he presides over the Albanian, Bulgarian, Czechoslovakian, Georgian, Greek, Polish, Romanian, Russian and Ukrainian Orthodox churches.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills One in Medellin; Police Seize Two Tons of Cocaine
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded late Saturday in front of police headquarters in the cocaine-trafficking center of Medellin, killing one civilian and wounding 14, police said. Meanwhile, police reported seizing more than two tons of cocaine, packaged and ready to be sent to the United States. They said it was hidden in an underground storage locker on a farm in northern Colombia. In the northwestern city of Medellin, the car bomb with more than 80 pounds of dynamite exploded near the police headquarters downtown, causing damage to nearby shops and a school, said the city's police chief, Col. Jorge Ferrero. In a live radio interview, Ferrero said a bystander died at a local hospital after being wounded in the bombing. Three of those wounded were in critical condition at the hospital, he said. He said there were no police casualties. Police were searching for a suspect who activated the bomb and fled, he said. The bombing was the fifth this year in Medellin. On Friday, police deactivated a car bomb packed with about 450 pounds of dynamite in the city. Since Friday, police reported seizing more than 3,000 pounds of dynamite that the Medellin drug cartel was reportedly planning to use for car bombings. Authorities blame the Medellin cocaine cartel for car bombings and other terrorist attacks that have killed hundreds of people in the last eleven months. The violence followed a U.S.-backed government crackdown on the cocaine trade. A police statement, read by the RCN radio network, said the 4,228 pounds of cocaine was seized Friday in a raid on a farm near the town of Caucasia, about 250 miles north of Bogota. Also found on the farm were an electric generator and equipment for processing cocaine, the statement said. Already this year, Colombian authorities have found and destroyed more than 63,000 pounds of cocaine in an unprecedented crackdown on the country's drug cartels. The latest seizure occurred as about 2,000 police officers and army soldiers continued to search in the central Magdalena River region for Pablo Escobar, the reputed leader of the Medellin cartel. Police say Escobar, accompanied by several bodyguards, is fleeing their pursuit in the region, where the terrain alternates between steep mountains and dense jungle. Four suspected drug terrorists were captured in Bogota and another in Medellin, the national police chief, Gen. Miguel Gomez, said at a press conference late Friday. Gomez added that police in the city of Pereira had captured another suspected cartel member on Friday. The suspect, Otoniel Gonzalez, is the seventh most important member of the cartel, Gomez said. Gunmen allegedly working for the cartel continued their attacks against police in Medellin, killing two more policemen late Friday. Three of the assailants were killed when police returned fire, a police communique said. Gunmen have shot and killed 142 police officers in the city this year. Most of the attacks have been blamed on the Medellin cartel, which is said to be offering a bounty of over $4,000 for each policeman killed.

DOC.HEAD: `Jaws' Theme Played for Underwater Music Festival in Reef
DOC.DATELINE: LOOE KEY NATIONAL MARINE SANCTUARY, Fla. (AP)
DOC.TEXT: More than 600 scuba divers and schools of colorful fish were treated to a three-hour concert in the scenic coral reefs of the Florida Keys on Saturday. The selections for the 6th Annual Underwater Music Festival, broadcast from five speakers into the underwater preserve, ranged from reggae to Tchaikovsky. They included the theme from the motion picture ``Jaws.'' ``I just wanted to give them something to think about,'' laughed disc jockey Barry Scot of WWUS radio, which sponsored the festival to educate divers about reef protecton and conservation. Each of the speakers was connected to above-water receivers that picked up radio signals from the nearby station on Big Pine Key. ``It was like listening to music in three dimension,'' said Kelly LaComb of Key West. ``The sound was so clear. It seemed like it was going through your body.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Boy Scout Spared Death in Fatal Beating of Guard
DOC.TEXT: A judge overruled a jury's death penalty recommendation for a former Boy Scout convicted of fatally beating a security guard with a wrought-iron pink flamingo. Palm Beach County Circuit Judge Walter N. Colbath Jr. told a rapt courtroom Friday that he felt anguish deciding the fate of 23-year-old Charles Young. Police testified that Young bludgeoned security guard Leslie Skomp with the decorative flamingo when confronted during a late night break-in at a produce market here. After Young's conviction in April, the jury voted 9-3 to send him to the electric chair. But Colbath concluded Young ``is the product of one of the most dysfunctional families, spanning three generations, ever presented to this court.'' Young's grandparents were alcoholics; he was physically abused by his stepfather, as was his mother, and he was left mentally disturbed, the judge said. ``None of the above excuses the defendant's cruel and atrocious conduct on the night of Dec. 1, 1987,'' Colbath said. ``It does, however, explain why the defendant, who had lived his life as a fantasy, suddenly snapped and lost control when faced with the reality of being caught red-handed in a burglary by the victim.'' Young faces at least 25 years in prison without parole. Related robbery, theft and burglary convictions could keep him in prison another 28 years. ``You are a likeable young man. I think with the proper treatment, you would have a lot to offer,'' the judge said as Young was led away. ``Good luck, Charlie.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-America's Young Woman, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0625,0286
DOC.HEAD: America's Young Woman of the Year From Illinois
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7, bgngn, `The judging...' with 3 grafs to show additional $2,000 given out by COca-Cola; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Illinois's Sara Helena Martin was named America's Young Woman of the Year Saturday night and took home a $30,000 college scholarship she said she would spend to become a linguist. ``I'm just numb,'' the 19-year-old Miss Martin of Schaumburg said, receiving hugs from the 49 other contestants who competed for shares of a total $75,000 in scholarships. ``The way I got here was being true to myself, believing in my own values.'' Runners-up were Seema Sueko Ahmed, 17, of Honolulu, and Mississippi's Rosalie Landicho Reyes, 17, of Waynesboro. Miss Ahmed received a $15,000 scholarship and Miss Reyes was awarded a $10,000 scholarship. The 50 participants displayed their talents _ in everything from opera singing to an impersonation of Michael Jackson _ in a stage production Saturday night at the Mobile Civic Center before some 2,000 cheering family members and friends. The rest of the prizes were parceled out in individual categories on Thursday, Friday and earlier Saturday. The judging focused on six categories: scholastic achievement; spirit; fitness; presence and composure; creative and performing arts, and on the basis of a personal interview with the judges. Six awards of $500 were given in each category, for a total of $18,000. Coca-Cola Co. gave an additional $2,000 in the Coca-Cola Spirit Award to Montana's Alycia Nathe of Plentywood, Mont. The program, which began in 1958, was known as America's Junior Miss until the name was changed last year.

DOC.HEAD: Grounded `Mesquite' Laid to Rest
DOC.TEXT: The wrecked Coast Guard cutter Mesquite was scuttled into a watery grave in Lake Superior on Saturday to become a tourist attraction for sports divers. ``She is on the bottom,'' said Capt. Jimmie Hobaugh, who commands the Coast Guard station at Sault Ste. Marie. The 180-foot cutter ran aground Dec. 4 off Keweenaw Point, and was battered against rocks for several days, leaving the hull in pieces. The sinking had to wait until bulkhead cracks were welded shut so the Mesquite could be towed to her resting place, said Petty Officer Frank Jennings, a Coast Guard spokesman at regional headquarters in Cleveland. Salvagers removed excess air from the tanks before sealing them, to make sure the ship sank, he said. A 250-foot barge was brought in to tow the Mesquite two miles south to Keystone Bay, to become part of the proposed Keweenaw Underwater Preserve. Before scuttling, commercial salvagers removed anything of value. Hobaugh said what remained ``is just a piece of junk.'' ``It's like when a person dies,'' he said. ``The soul goes away and you've got a sack of oats left. That's what a minister told me once to help me deal with picking up bodies. It's the same thing.'' The Mesquite's captain, Lt. Cmdr. John Lynch, faces court martial on negligence charges. He was criticized for assigning too few crew members to check the ship's position. Two other ship's officers were reprimanded in the grounding. Officials say it would cost $35 million to replace the 48-year-old cutter.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawks Agree to End Blockade of Montreal Bridge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Indians agreeing to lift blockade of bridge near Montreal, demonstration near bridge; CORRECTS date when bridge blockade began; CORRECTS spelling of Oka reservation to `Kanehsatake'. No pickup. ^LaserPhotos NY23, MTL2
DOC.TEXT: Armed Mohawk Indians embroiled in a land dispute with authorities agreed Saturday to lift a bridge blockade near Montreal after a provincial official promised to reduce the police contingent in this town. The agreement was announced after Quebec Native Affairs Minister John Ciaccia met for more than six hours with Indian representatives in an effort to end the dispute that has left one police officer dead. The meeting came as Indians manned barricades at a reservation near Oka and blockaded the Mercier Bridge linking Montreal with its populous suburbs onthe south shore of the St. Lawrence River. Ciaccia said the bridge blockade could be lifted as early as Sunday, but he refused to elaborate on the terms of the agreement. But Mohawk representative Ellen Gabriel said the Indians had agreed to reopen the bridge in return for a ``significant reduction'' of the police presence in Oka. Highways leading to the bridge were blockaded Wednesday by Mohawks of the Kahnawake reserve following an armed clash between provincial police and Mohawks manning barricades on the reservation near Oka. Since the clash, Mohawks and police have been locked in a tense standoff in Oka. The Indians have refused to take down their barricades. Ciaccia said the talks Saturday resulted in the ``beginnings of proposals'' to end the Oka confrontation. ``You should all be very happy that we are announcing a solution for one very serious problem and the beginnings of a solution for the entire problem,'' he told reporters. Ciaccia refused to elaborate on the proposals, saying he must first consult with the provincial government. He said he would return to Oka on Sunday to continue the talks. Gabriel also refused to discuss details of the negotiations, but said she is optimistic a solution can be found to the Oka dispute. The confrontation has left one police officer dead after Wednesday's shootout with Mohawks manning barricades in Oka, 20 miles west of Montreal. It is unclear if the officer was shot by Mohawks or fellow police. The Mohawks from the Kanehsatake Indian community set up barricades at Oka to stop the municipality from expanding a golf course onto what the Indians claim is ancestral territory. Mohawk activists from the Kahnawake reserve had threatened to destroy the Mercier Bridge if police moved to dismantle their blockade. One banner strung across a trailer near the bridge said ``Stop Canadian Apartheid and Amerindian genocide.'' The blockade of the bridge has sparked widespread anger among local white residents. The highway to the bridge passes through the Indian reservation. The Quebec provincial police riot squad was called out Saturday for the second straight night as angry white residents milled around the edge of the reserve, at times trying to storm police barricades around the area. The Quebec police were backed up by a force of about 100 Royal Canadian Mounted Police. About 2,000 people chanted ``We want the army!'' and jeered at police officers who protected people whom the demonstrators suspected of being Indians. Witnesses said the crowd attempted to rush the barricades but police pushed them back. The local residents said they wanted to prevent the Mohawks from leaving the reservation since the Indians were hindering them from getting to Montreal. Both Mohawks and other local residents have complained that food is running out in the area, which has been sealed off by police. Quebec provincial police spokesman Pierre Rochefort said reports that people are being prevented from carrying food past police barricades are ``rumors.'' He described the police action as ``traffic control.'' Police blocked non-residents and the media from the Oka area. The Canadian military confirmed Friday that 40 members of the 2nd Combat Engineers have been stationed in Cornwall, Ontario, near the Akwesasne Mohawk reserve. It straddles the borders of Quebec, Ontario and New York state. The move is believed to have been made because of fears that Mohawk Indians from the Akwesasne reserve may try to occupy the international bridge linking Ontario and New York state.

DOC.HEAD: Tenn. Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Spanking Client
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer accused of spanking a client pleaded guilty Friday to misdemeanor assault charges and agreed to surrender his law license for five years. Smyrna attorney John Kersey was charged with assault after a client accused him of spanking her May 25 at his office during a consultation for a divorce. The 27-year-old woman told police that Kersey locked her in his office, quizzed her on multiplication tables and threatened to hit her if she missed a figure. She said he then ordered her to read a magazine, spanked her and made demeaning remarks. During the hearing before Circuit Court Judge James Clayton, Kersey also agreed to seek counseling and serve an 11-month, 29-day probation. Since his June arrest, 11 other women had come forward to accuse Kersey of similar actions. No other charges will be pursued against him because the accusations are more than a year old and have passed the statute of limitations, District Attorney Guy Dotson said. Kersey attempted suicide July 3 by shooting himself in the chest and had been hospitalized. Dotson said Kersey would leave immediately for counseling.

The agency that ran nuclear weapons production in the 1940s rejected secret advice to study cancer risks for its workers, even though it knew some were exposed to large doses of radiation, documents show. Records of the Atomic Energy Commission also show that airborne emissions of radiation continued at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington state from the plant's start-up in 1944 until at least the mid-1950s. The AEC was a predecessor to the Energy Department, which owns all the government's nuclear arms factories. The government first acknowledged the Hanford problems publicly in 1986, although much information about radiation releases there is still classified as secret. On Thursday, a panel of health experts disclosed that one in 20 residents living near Hanford, on the Columbia River near Richland, Wash., between late 1944 and December 1947 absorbed a level of radiation equal to 1,200 times what the Energy Department now considers a safe limit.

President Bush is eager to sign civil rights legislation aimed at drawing millions of disabled Americans into the work force and marketplace. ``This legislation will serve as a declaration of independence for millions of persons with disabilities in this country,'' Bush said Friday after a 91-6 Senate vote sent the Americans With Disabilities Act to the White House. ``It will change the way we live forever,'' said the chief Senate sponsor, Democrat Tom Harkin of Iowa. In a dramatic conclusion of nine months of debate on the bill, Harkin addressed the Senate in sign language as a tribute to his brother Frank, who is deaf.

Albania says 100,000 people have rallied in support of its Communist leaders, who told them the thousands of asylum-seekers who left the country are social outcasts. The rally Friday appeared to be an attempt by Albania's leadership to demonstrate a majority of the country's 3.1 million residents still supports the Stalinist government, the last in Europe. Meanwhile, a French-chartered ferry carrying 545 Albanian asylum-seekers was due to arrive in Marseille, France today. About 4,500 Albanians were ferried across the Adriatic Sea to Italy on Friday. Most of those remaining in foreign missions in the Albanian capital of Tirana were expected to make their own way to freedom within days.

The Republican Party is urging its local leaders to rally behind President Bush as he considers tax increases that many in the GOP wish he would go back to opposing. The president's abrupt switch on taxes late last month caught most Republicans off guard, and left many questioning why Bush would abandon his campaign pledge with crucial 1990 elections just four months away. After initially lying low in the tax debate, party leaders came out swinging Friday, painting Bush's turnabout as a tough but bold move to help erase the federal deficit. Republican Illinois Gov. James Thompson said Bush ``had the courage to summon up the political will to do what was right for the country.''

While the government is redesigning currency to thwart counterfeiters, it ought to make the bills more attractive, says a man who used to run the Treasury's money-producing agency. ``The principles and history of a country are recounted in the art of bank notes,'' Robert J. Leuver told the Senate Banking Committee on Friday. ``We seem to have lost the art, majesty and history provided in our national bank notes of 1896, silver certificates of 1896 and the beautiful $2 bill of 1976.'' ``The `Tin Lizzy' (vintage car) on the back of the $10 bill harkens to a different time and does not afford the counterfeit detection we need,'' said Leuver, a former chief of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing who now directs the American Numismatic Association. Leuver said most of the anti-counterfeiting deterrents built into currency are less effective than they could be because of the 50-year-old design of the bills.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Touch 3,000 With Boost From Fed
DOC.TEXT: Using ammunition provided by the Federal Reserve, the stock market hit a lofty target this past week. Shortly after 1:30 p.m. on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average crossed the 3,000 level for the first time, reaching that landmark faster than even many bullish analysts thought possible just a few weeks ago. Analysts gave Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, credit for making it happen when it did. Greenspan surprised Wall Street's legion of Fed-watchers in a congressional appearance Thursday with what appeared to be a clear signal that the Fed was making a significant shift in credit policy. He told the Senate Banking Committee that the central bank was ready to ease monetary conditions, fostering lower interest rates, in response to rising evidence of a squeeze on bank credit. In so doing, he hinted strongly that the Fed had moved closer to mollifying critics in the Bush administration and on Wall Street who had been urging the central bank to take steps to avert a potential recession. The response in the financial markets was immediate, as visions of more plentiful money and a stimulus to the sluggish economy sent traders scrambling to buy both stocks and bonds. In addition, many analysts said, Greenspan's comments were taken as reassurance for investors who have been worrying that a stringent new approach among bank lending officers and regulators might put a choke-hold on the economy. ``I think the most important thing he said is to acknowledge that he is as concerned about current lending practices in banking as we are,'' said Hugh Johnson at First Albany Corp. in Albany, N.Y. ``We hadn't received that kind of acknowledgment before.'' On Friday, activities by the Fed in the money markets appeared to confirm the message that it was seeking to encourage short-term interest rates to decline. But with all those promising developments, observers said the markets still faced obstacles. In the past, they noted, expressions of willingness from the Fed to try to avert recessions have not always meant immediate success on that score. Furthermore, they added, any commitment by the central bank to easier credit could waver should the news on inflation start to turn uglier at any point. The price of gold, widely regarded as an sensitive measure of inflationary expectations, sounded a faintly ominous note by rallying along with stocks and bonds on the prospect of stimulus by the Fed. Still, stock-market investors made their endorsement of Greenspan's move easy to read. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed Friday at 2,980.20, up 75.25 from the week before. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 4.55 to 200.33; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 7.90 to 468.44, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 5.12 at 363.99. Volume on the Big Board averaged 171.27 million shares a day, up from 125.07 million the week before. Anticipation of a Fed move toward easier credit increased on Wall Street with a recent push in the White House and Congress toward a plan for reducing the federal budget deficit. Any moves to cut government spending or raise taxes would represent a tightening of fiscal policy, which would stand to slow the economy further. So many commentators began looking for the Fed to adopt a counterbalancing approach by relaxing its monetary policy. Those hopes seem to have been fulfilled. Now stock and bond traders can set up watch to see whether the Fed can get results to realize its new stated intentions.

DOC.HEAD: Takeovers Back in the News, But Nowhere Near the Rage of Late 1980s
DOC.TEXT: For a while it looked like the good old days, with takeovers, defensive alliances and stock rumors coming one after another: two phone giants merging, a French hotelier buying an American budget motel chain, two technology companies forming a strategic joint venture. There even was wild speculation that Mitsubishi Group, the Japanese industrial conglomerate that made the planes used to dive-bomb Pearl Harbor, would buy a big piece of an old World War II aviation adversary, McDonnell Douglas Corp. But that rumor was denied, and a closer look at the deals done this past week showed they bore little in common with a typical wild week of takeover news in the last half of the 1980s. For one thing, there was an absence of junk bonds, the risky IOUs used to bankroll many of the high-profile transactions of the past decade. The corporate buyers of 1990 must carry less speculative tools, like cash, stock or secured bank loans, partly because attempts to peddle junk-bond debt to raise takeover money are largely futile now. The rising number of junk-bond defaults has scared most buyers away. Another difference in the deals of this past week was that none of the buyers were unfriendly outside investors motivated by the greedy quick money mentality that colored many other high-profile takeovers of the past decade. On the contrary, all had a direct business interest in what they were buying. The most obvious example also was the biggest, not only of the week but the year. Contel Corp., the nation's No. 3 independent telephone company, accepted a takeover offer from GTE Corp, the No. 1 independent, in a stock swap valued at $6 billion. The merger will create a leading operator of cellular phone systems, one of the fastest-growing segments of the telecommunications industry. Both partners called their marriage ``a perfect combination.'' The week's other prominent deal was the French lodging company Accor SA's $1.3 billion agreement to buy Motel 6, one of the best-known purveyors of budget roadside lodging in the United States. Accor thus will become the biggest operator of low-priced hotel rooms in the world. The deal also was notable because of the identity of the seller: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. The New York investment group made leveraged buyout a household term last decade and holds the record for the biggest LBO in history, the $25 billion debt-financed acquisition of RJR Nabisco Inc. early last year. The ultimate wisdom of Kohlberg's RJR deal remains unclear. But its purchase of Motel 6 five years ago appears to have been a sound choice. Investors who participated in that debt-financed transaction will make a 21.5 percent rate of return on their money when Accor completes its purchase. The third notable corporate transaction of the week was a strategic alliance by International Business Machines Corp. and Diebold Inc. to manufacture and market automated bank teller machines worldwide. The combined ATM operation will be the nation's largest and will enable each company to benefit from the other's strengths without a costly investment, a major motivation for many companies that have sought joint ventures recently. The developments of the past week reflect the underlying themes of a long-term strategy that has shaped a growing number of other recent takeovers. Philip Morris Cos., for example, is buying a Swiss candymaker for $3.8 billion. ConAgra Inc. is purchasing Beatrice Co. for $1.34 billion. In both instances, the buyer's existing businesses will be strengthened. In what may be an ironic twist, the increased takeover action has coincided with a reluctance by many corporations to take advantage of tough anti-takeover laws that many legislatures have enacted to protect state businesses. Earlier this month, for example, H.J. Heinz Co. said it voluntarily would relinquish the anti-takeover protections offered by its home state, Pennsylvania, which enacted the nation's toughest anti-takeover law last spring. In other business and economic news this past week: _The nation's top banker surprised the markets by acknowledging the possibility of a credit crunch and his willingness to ease interest rates. The remarks by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan energized Wall Street, pushed stocks to a record and briefly vaulted the Dow Jones average over 3,000. _Readings of the economy's health suggested reduced chances of recession. The government said retail sales rose sharply in June, the first big gain in five months, while inflation remained moderate. Major automakers said sales strengthened in mid-July, extending a sales gain in the troubled industry that began in June. _The savings & loan scandal grew in severity. The former head of a big Texas thrift was indicted on 17 counts of fraud and other crimes, President Bush felt compelled to publicly defend son Neil for his alleged role in the collapse of a Colorado thrift, and the Senate passed a crime bill that would punish high-level S&L executives convicted of fraud with life imprisonment. _The first jury trial against a Wall Street professional incriminated by notorious inside trader Ivan Boesky ended with a conviction on four counts and a mistrial on 26 others. Defendant John A. Mulheren Jr., a stock speculator and former Boesky confidante, said he will appeal the guilty verdict.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules for Filipino Seamen
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge in Washington state ruled Friday in favor of 21 Filipino seamen who claimed a Japanese steamship company failed to pay them 80 percent of their salaries on eight wood-shipping trips to Washington state. The seamen could collect up to $40 million, which would be the largest wage judgment entered in maritime history, said attorneys and supporters of the plaintiffs. U.S. District Judge Jack Tanner did not set a dollar figure in ruling for the Filipinos, said the court clerk's office in Tacoma, Wash. The 21 were suing the Innui Steamship Co., Ltd., a subsidiary of Japan's second largest shipping firm, Mitsui. The seamen charged the company used ``double bookkeeping'' to defraud them, and forced them to sign bogus contracts and wage receipts for wages never paid. ``This scam has been going on for years and not just on this ship,'' said Richard J. Dotson, attorney for the plaintiffs. ``This victory sends a clear message to all offending ship owners: if you're going to cheat and mistreat your crew, don't sail into an American port.'' According to the suit, the M-V Pine Forest carried timber on eight trips between Washington state and Japan. Trial testimony showed the workers received less than 20 percent of the wages due them. The underpayment was discovered when a ship chaplain visited an injured crew member at an Anchorage, Alaska, hospital. He called in the Center for Seafarers' Rights, which provided an attorney. The announcement of the ruling was made in New York at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey, which is home to the Center for Seafarers' Rights. The institute is a 157-year-old non-profit agency that deals with the maritime industry and merchant seafarers around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Soup Co. Projects Fiscal Results
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. said Friday the company would achieve nearly break-even net earnings this year due to a major restructuring announced last month. Campbell's chief executive officer, David W. Johnson, made the announcement to analysts at a meeting in New York City. He said earnings for the period ending July 31 will be flat as a result of after-tax charges of $247 million against net income in the fourth quarter. In June, Campbell announced it would put up for sale its U.S. and Canadian fresh foods and fresh produce businesses, with combined net sales of more than $300 million, and close or sell a score of plants. The company said it planned to concentrate on its more profitable units. The company has been ``diligently working to prune those parts of the business that have been dragging down our earnings,'' Campbell told the analysts. Campbell posted a profit of $13.1 million, or 10 cents a share, in fiscal 1989 on revenues of $5.67 billion, a sharp drop from profits of $274.1 million, or $2.12 per share, on revenues of $4.87 billion the year before. The decline was due to previous restructuring costs. Campbell's recent sluggish performance and depressed stock price have made it the target of frequent takeover rumors. Some members of the founding Dorrance family, which owns a major stake, have urged a sale of the entire company. Over the next few years, Johnson said Campbell's plans to boost its earnings per share by 20 percent annually. He said the company also plans to achieve at least a 20 percent return on equity and a 20 percent cash return on assets.
